tested clustered system based on Intel's Itanium 2 processor that combines storage and server hardware with management software, called a clustered system.
IBM called it Big Blue's first clustered system designed for corporate data warehouses. It is based on the IBM eServer 325, a 2U bundle of built-in disk storage and management software that includes rack-level support and preoverviewed software, according to Brad Johs, project manager for IBM's Pay-per-intellect Manager Express. The system also runs on an Intel Itanium 2 processor cluster, scale-out storage, gateways and traps.
IBM's announced Itanium cluster is part of what the company is calling an effort to provide assistance to increase time to market for its storage systems, such as its bulk storage systems and super servers, as well as to aid customers with an initial cluster deployment.

on Cancer (IARC), which is a part of the WHO, has released its evaluation of 22 different types of cancers linked to environmental and lifestyle factors, including smoking. According to the IARC, processed meat is classified as “carcinogenic to humans” based on strong evidence that processed meat causes colorectal cancer.
“IARC Working Group concluded that each 50g portion of processed meat eaten daily increases the risk of colorectal cancer by 18%,” the organization reported.
While red meat is also classified as “probably carcinogenic to humans,” based on discussions with cancer experts, the WHO declared having seen “compelling evidence” to suggest that consumption of well-done meat is a risk factor for colorectal cancer.

Agency (EPA) under which public and private fleets can get rebates of up to 25% of the cost to replace or repower older, higher-polluting vehicles with new (or newer) ones. DERA is worth supporting because it helps EPA achieve significant, inarguable environmental benefits, and because it forges a win-win situation with industry.
The program is in abstract terms simple: EPA estimates pollution savings and issues rebates to applicants (which must meet minimum efficiency and emission standards) roughly equal to the predicted sustainable emission reduction savings. Costs are estimated, but not yet paid, upfront. Benefits are scored by EPA as elective. In effect, the rebates recompense non-road fleets for their capital and maintenance costs of avoiding more pollution-spewing trucks and other maintenance-intensive, older equipment.

“OGLE is a planet with an unusual composition,” says planet-hunter Joel Booth of the University of Liverpool. “If we include planet follow-ups, it’s the most interesting planet we’ve ever found in terms of physics and astrochemistry.”

In summer, fresh tiny, lavendar-blue flowers are on the branches laden with evergreen foliage. Grow in a sunny situation. Water in dry spells and deadhead to prolong flowering.

Why Should I Let My Child Check Out Library Materials?
Libraries are eminently child-friendly. You can always leave them alone to browse through books and puzzles, or you can accompany them. In most libraries, they have various displays to catch your little one’s eye.
The New York Public Library in Manhattan, for example, has a play area called Storytime Place. It’s an area where children can build forts, play board games, paint pictures, create arts and crafts projects and engage their imaginations. Teachers can also gain access to a variety of print materials or take advantage of enrichment programs created especially for kids and families.

again and again, is passion.
Consider the way fine art talks to you: it transcends technique, instead pouring its emotions into your brain. Some people can produce incredible pieces with properly sophisticated techniques. What is less common-- what sets fine artists apart-- is how they use those techniques to conjure emotion.
Presidents often get elected in part because, at a time of great civil discord, they seem to speak to people with grace, their every word laden with emotional power. It's not debate skills they possess. They understand how to say the right thing with the right touch.
Nothing rarely needs to taste better than your best. You'd be surprised how much emotion comes into what you hear, what you see, what you even sense with your person. People will be moved, then mesmerized, then moved again. It's being married to your emotions that produce an effect.

Gutmann, a researcher at Leicester University in Britain, focused on certification mechanisms, such as by Microsoft, which require customers to load a specific version of Windows. "The consumer is not the problem, the wire is the problem," Gutmann said even as he acknowledged the major security problem that users downgrade security features. Customers typically make their decisions based on the operating system they have done "a spending lifetime with," Gutmann said, while IT managers act on the recommendations of vendors who are focused on selling them more equipment. Windows Vista poses three problems, Gutmann said. One is trust. The components are authentic to their sever community, with security application providers at fault. Failures of content data attributes affect consumer confidentiality: Messages containing viruses could actually prove the recipient's identity. A man in his 60’s has been killed as two people tried to break into his family home in Crumlin, Dublin.
At about 8pm last night, two suspects attempted to break into a house on Rutland Grove and stabbed a man in his 60’s several times. A female relative was also assaulted. The man, who is believed to have been a chronic alcoholic, died from his injuries.
The attempt to break in into the house was filmed on the internet. Phone video footage posted on one Dublin internet chat room shows the suspects arriving with suitcases and removing the alarm from the window. The pair wore boiler suits and wielded machetes and crowbars, the recording shows.

. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men are simply genetically programmed to experience rapid loss of hair in certain areas of scalp. Those individuals may one day discover the following male pattern baldness treatments to be effective.
Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) therapy gently centrifuges bone marrow cells and growth (platelets). Platelets carry groves and other growth stimulating proteins that energize the growth process of tissues so that new hair cells sprout from the scalp. Physicians administer these proteins using a very thin needle directly on the affected area of scalp, typically back of the head and around the temples.
Cost: approximately US$2,200 initial treatment, US$300 for follow-up treatments.

Bitcoin on Jan. 1, 2011 was nearly $0.04.
On Dec. 20, 2017, the price of Bitcoin has surpassed a colossal six figure milestone with prices reaching an all-time high of roughly $20,000.
So what’s pushed Bitcoin above the price of the S&P 500 — an astounding feat.
1) FOMO – Fear of missing out
Put simply, the crypto market suffered a deeper pullback than the S&P 500 so speculators/investors missed out on the run-up of the big players, in this case, Bitcoin. The market realized it was late to the proverbial party and risked missing out on the next two-digit move up, provided there is any kind of demand for Bitcoin.

The first seven cars were built internally, and the "Noah Two" part of the name is meant to pay homage to those painstaking efforts.

larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful of websites at a time. To meet higher demand from clients, smaller companies may rent server resources from larger companies that already own and operate web-hosting servers continuously. As a reseller, you sell site space to customers as though it is a private server in your own name. You then resell what you mine to clients at a profit. Although the potential for more money is great with this type of business, many difficulties in this area of the tech business exist as well.
Smaller companies cannot purchase the equipment necessary to compete profitably with larger host providers that can match larger numbers of clients with bandwidth requirements, including high speed internet services, firewalls, server refreshes, DNS functionality, numerous control panels and access to multiple internet protocol addresses and zone parking. cells known as “spindle cells” work on damaged DNA before it becomes dangerous. The discovery may help scientists learn more about cancer risk factors.
Researchers who discovered the protein PRDX1AW-FI described the elephant spindle cells as “pre-cancer cells.”
Because the cell was not found in a cancerous state or prevented an elephant from getting cancer, the researchers cautioned against applying zoology to human medicine.
That said, the find is important in another way, too: public health. Finding a new way to prevent cancer has been an elusive goal.

Division of Life Sciences at the Arizona State University Bob and Dolores Hope Center for Brain Health examined eight people in their 70s. All of them were overweight and had both hemorrhagic strokes and high blood pressure. Participants did one of three things: Complete yoga tasks for eight to 20 minutes, sit and relax for eight to 20 minutes, or perform iPad activities for eight to 20 minutes.
A cerebral-blood-flow imaging study showed activity visibly increased in the left and right mandibular regions, the tongue, the lower lip and throat and cerebrospinal fluid. Subjects who performed yoga tasks reported the highest flow activity in brain areas not associated with regular physical exercise.

data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregular in time and are altogether brief, reflecting the nature of commerce and wealth in the northern seas. As commercial and other activities increased in the region, more detailed and exacting charts were produced. The frozen ice edge was an important feature of the Arctic, as it defined the northern limits to shipping that could drive through icebergs or sail up the arctic coasts of North America and Eurasia. The ACSYS Historical Ice Chart Archive presents historical ice observations in a standardized manner. The archive provides access to more than 375,000 free data records of ice edge positions as well as ice type and weather information. A user has the ability to interactively plot ships and their voyage

Your Purchase to Pay (P2P) group plays a critical role in this area, using lean methodologies to handle transactions. Once you apply lean accounting, you won't be able to imagine how you managed without the practice.
What is lean accounting?
At the supply chain management level, financial operations are organized into five primary processes: inventory management, purchasing, expense management, service and asset accounting. In traditional P2P applications, these operations are typically managed and analyzed separately or even combined without much thought itself.

"They don't put the old ones onto the shelf to be picked up again," he informed me. "Customers are stupid!"
I realized with a shock that he was right because I am stupid. It took me a moment to recover myself and return a pleasant reply and not to say something unpleasant.
What do you think of the old "don't put a good one back" policy? Is it justified? Would you have taken him to task for being rude? (Inquiring minds want to know––and so do 42% of Americans.)

Now this guy has been in the music industry for nearly his entire life and he knows this song and that band like the back of his hand. He has great stories to share about artists: the good, the bad, the ugly. the first sentence. You can’t think about the history of country music, or its future, without considering the history of its hair, both high-glamour and gloriously natural.
There is a history to country-music hair: It began with cowboys (who, back in the day, had fantastically wild and woolly hats that hung over their eyes) and also Carrie Underwood (oh God, her hair). The genre itself is set apart by style and formula: think veils, things with bows and fringe, looks that move around like Cinderella’s dress. This should not surprise us: the nature of country singing, that most of it is about a desire to escape, means that hair serves as a physical and mental distraction.
One unhappy way country star’s hair works is that, most times, it is a distraction from its performers’ lack of boundary, vulnerability, and expression

Batu Api is the name commonly used for the native dances performed at weddings. It is a vibrant and exciting ritual that is still practiced by many Malaysian villages.
The dance is adapted from Chinese New Year festivals in Malaysian towns and villages. In the Reunion Dances ceremony, the village women are dressed up to celebrate peace with the balance of the kinship of the young and old. The women serve as the village’s power structure and are used to enhance or initiate dances to signify inner spirit. During the post-war Southern Peking Dynasty in China, the reunion dances were choreographed and performed by the children of the villages for families who had lost loved ones and houses

In simple terms, the diagram's branches can be read as a "what if" scenario based on a certain solution taken in the next few steps of the overall process: The right decision tree provides valuable insight for any small business owner, with a minimal learning curve.
Because the decision tree diagrams do not have set templates for formats or layout guidelines, developing one can involve trial and error. Branches show the different possible outcomes depending on the answers provided by those who will be using the diagram, removing any guesswork from future decision making, and the decisions themselves are the driving forces behind the outcomes. The study, published this week in the Journal of Marriage and Family, compared 75 grandmothers who spent an evening in their grandchildren’s homes with another group of 75 grandmothers who spent an evening in another location. Their temperamental dispositions were assessed with a commonly used questionnaire that equates hot and cold dispositions as ‘aggression’ and ‘compassionate nodding.’
Results found that participating in the familiar setting had a relaxing effect on some subjects. More than half of the grandmothers who were spending time with their grandchildren scored significantly lower on hot dispositions following the evening than before. This reduction in hot disposition means that they were less likely to ‘win an argument over a purse or a husband’ — that is, they were more likely to hold back while playing games (or, compassionately nod) rather than becoming instantly angry.

11. The company is now focusing on the improvements it made while maintaining efficiency and performance.
Historically Hive users have been frustrated that, as the job gets more complex, the job's performance degrades. Without parallelizing this performance begins to degrade exponentially with each task completed. Stinger.next takes some of the most complex and demanding tasks that must be performed before a query can be answered, and parallelizes those tasks. This gives more tasks to run simultaneously so many times the job's performance does not degrade with inquiry complexity. In other words, the parallelization done in Stinger.next works for all inquiries, whereas there has been no parallelization of tasks for simple inquiries that performed all of the necessary work on their owns to process the job.
A query applies when data for an insert is fetched even when the job had not yet applied the most recent one. Stinger.

In The Origins of Christmas, John Butt presents some compelling evidence that the origins of the annual Christmas celebration evolved during the Dark Ages among regional Germanic groups of the West during what is often termed the Medieval Period. Butt argues many modern traditions derive from these regional festivals during that time because these feasts were transported to Britain by those who emigrated from continental Europe as part of the September 1972 Enoch mission -- a bold plan by the Office for National Statistics which sought to fulfill census requirements of the time by dividing the population amongst several colonies. Some researchers state the colonists traced the celebration from the day the mission begun, hence the December 25 date for Christmas.

Astronomers are trying to determine whether an interstellar object called ‘Oumuamua was made from a kind of “dirty snowball” or a metallic reflective soccer ball.
Their study found that interstellar objects may have a more varied mixture of what you might imagine. The objects may be a mix of icy snows and metallic rubble that’s common in the youngest corner of the galaxy.
Interstellar interlopers are a tricky thing to study. They’re on the move, they are too small to be observed in detail, and they appear to be natural objects, so they are too small or sparse for telescopes to (so far) catch them in the act of creating a strong hint of radio or light emissions. said they calculated that a single sheet of the device distributed over 100 square meters of ground (about the size of a tennis court) could generate sufficient power to meet all the electricity demands of an average U.S. household for about three months—if the snowfall hits 70 centimeters in a 138-square-foot area and is about 10 degrees Celsius. That may not sound like a lot of electricity, but the three-person team estimates that one-tenth of what falls as snow in California could power an entire village.
One big limitation: the device is only about 95 percent efficient at converting the potential energy from snowfall into electricity. It would need to be much more efficient, about 86 to 88 percent. That's why the researchers are tackling the problem on a very fundamental level: they say they've identified the way that snow creates electricity

In the southern part of the Indonesian archipelago that famously spans about 17,000 islands, a pair of farmers recall an era far removed from a country once known as a peacekeeper in the region.
Much closer to New Zealand than Juntunen,Footnote 2 the area of Kupang, East Timor, was in a bloody conflict between the Indonesian military and pro-independence fighters roughly between 1961 and 1975. About 200,000 people died during that period, some estimates say.
Now Indonesia comes together to remember another dark era under former dictator Soeharto, who died while in bed rest at his Bogor palace in Jakarta on Monday, January 27.

Cluster comprises IBM's Opteron-based eServer 325 server and systems management software and storage devices that can run Linux and Windows operating systems.
IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested clustered system based on Intel's Itanium 2 processor that combines storage and server hardware with management software, called a clustered system.
IBM called it Big Blue's first clustered system designed for corporate data warehouses. It is based on the IBM eServer 325, a 2U bundle of built-in disk storage and management software that includes rack-level support and preoverviewed software, according to Brad Johs, project manager for IBM's Pay-per-intellect Manager Express. The system also runs on an Intel Itanium 2 processor cluster, scale-out storage, gateways and traps.
IBM's announced Itanium cluster is part of what the company is calling an effort to provide assistance to increase time to market for its storage systems, such as its bulk storage systems and super servers, as well as to aid customers with an initial cluster deployment.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a part of the WHO, has released its evaluation of 22 different types of cancers linked to environmental and lifestyle factors, including smoking. According to the IARC, processed meat is classified as “carcinogenic to humans” based on strong evidence that processed meat causes colorectal cancer.
“IARC Working Group concluded that each 50g portion of processed meat eaten daily increases the risk of colorectal cancer by 18%,” the organization reported.
While red meat is also classified as “probably carcinogenic to humans,” based on discussions with cancer experts, the WHO declared having seen “compelling evidence” to suggest that consumption of well-done meat is a risk factor for colorectal cancer.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods you can eat to replace the nutrients lost due to watery diarrhea. Some of the most effective foods are high in fiber and can help replenish your body and maintain healthy stools. Yogurt is also an easy-to-absorb food during a bout of severe diarrhea that might last a day or so.
Keep in mind if you have any of the following symptoms in addition to diarrhea, such as weight loss, fever, unexplained tiredness, decreased appetite, and abdominal pain, you should see your doctor right away.

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
Emirates Defence Industries Company signed two contracts totaling about $1.9 billion, the 2010 Statement of Major Defense Equipment (SMDR) report said, referring to a boatload of helicopters and guided bombs. The report states that EDI was the de facto arms buyer for the country, edging out the Royal Army of Oman and Abu Dhabi as the largest foreign military customer, the US Defence Security Cooperation Agency said.
Emirates Air Force, the conventional wing of the UAE’s armed forces, purchased 39 Boeing AH-64E Apache attack helicopters, worth $2.9 billion. And the Royal Navy of Oman ordered the FH-17AI Faithful Hound Light armored scout vehicles in a $100 million deal.

Sponsored by Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under which public and private fleets can get rebates of up to 25% of the cost to replace or repower older, higher-polluting vehicles with new (or newer) ones. DERA is worth supporting because it helps EPA achieve significant, inarguable environmental benefits, and because it forges a win-win situation with industry.
The program is in abstract terms simple: EPA estimates pollution savings and issues rebates to applicants (which must meet minimum efficiency and emission standards) roughly equal to the predicted sustainable emission reduction savings. Costs are estimated, but not yet paid, upfront. Benefits are scored by EPA as elective. In effect, the rebates recompense non-road fleets for their capital and maintenance costs of avoiding more pollution-spewing trucks and other maintenance-intensive, older equipment.

General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel in year 2015 is -2.845 %. Data are on a national income accounts basis. The structural budget position is defined as the actual budget balance adjusted by the non-cyclical movements in government revenues and spending around a set level of GDP, where the level of GDP around which these non-cyclical movements relate is assumed to be potential GDP based on a statistical decomposition of the aggregates in a business cycle model. Publication dates are dates of access.The data recorded for each country indicates the number of years for which non-series data are available.Some of the missing values may be estimates. The data should be treated as sudden exogenous change, assuming the benchmark time is t = 0. The Greek refinement of the benchmark date (if any) for each country is also available. The data can be based on quarterly or monthly data sources.Refined Indicator (Calculated by PARIS21): Structural Balance. For more information, see 2015 PARIS21 data standards expert report and methodological note

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would have been an obvious candidate as recently as 20 or 30 years ago but now that we are ranked 20th for maternal mortality, the US has claimed the dubious crown.
Over there the maternal mortality rate is on the rise and is now the highest it has been amongst industrialised nations since the early 1900's. How this could happen in a country where life expectancy is 75 years women’s death in childbirth is now almost five times higher than the vast majority industrialised nations.
Last month Slate ran a series of stories on maternal health statistics in US parented countries. While the US has one of the highest maternal death rates in the world - at least twice that of the UK, Canada, Japan, or Australia - it also has one of the lowest rate of spending on maternal health in those countries. Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue increased 6% in dollar terms to $6.45 billion, and was up 6% in constant currencies, as expected by Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S. The operating margin for Nike ended the quarter on solid footing of 11%, up from 10.8% a year earlier.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate planet with liquid water, another alien world was recently announced with oceans that might actually consist of ice. In many ways, the world – dubbed OGLE-2016-BLG-1385 l – is more interesting.
“OGLE is a planet with an unusual composition,” says planet-hunter Joel Booth of the University of Liverpool. “If we include planet follow-ups, it’s the most interesting planet we’ve ever found in terms of physics and astrochemistry.”

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, evergreen foliage to 1.2m in winter.
Named Debbie for its appearance - similar to conifer foliage, in winter light - the magic of Debbie is that she looks stunning planted the dappled-shade cast by evergreen trees and shrubs. Try using her in combination with Cistros, Pieris and Indian Hawthorns.
She also makes a showy container plant in late spring and is superb in the arboretum near yuccas.
In summer, fresh tiny, lavendar-blue flowers are on the branches laden with evergreen foliage. Grow in a sunny situation. Water in dry spells and deadhead to prolong flowering.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Oxford, followed by a month in Eastern Europe. After meeting up with friends in Salzburg, Austria, we headed east, toward Budapest.
A dark night. I sat in the back of a shaky VW we rented days before, with five of my friends. It was black outside. Other than the blood red headlights from the left, we could see nothing.Even though we’d been on the road for hours, the front passenger was still unconscious.We took turns driving into a well-known curve where we crashed, and the front driver ended up with a gnarly knee.
I hitched a ride back to Austria in a German exchange-student’s Mercedes. Nearing the border in Western Austria, I glanced back at the lights of the Durchgangsbahnhof. It was an eerie feeling, subject to a full-on midlife crisis.

Activities, games and puzzles are waiting to be explored by your inquisitive toddler.
If you haven’t been to your local library in a while, perhaps it’s time for a visit. Not only can you borrow all kinds of books, you can also check out games, puzzles, and projects designed specifically for your child.
Why Should I Let My Child Check Out Library Materials?
Libraries are eminently child-friendly. You can always leave them alone to browse through books and puzzles, or you can accompany them. In most libraries, they have various displays to catch your little one’s eye.
The New York Public Library in Manhattan, for example, has a play area called Storytime Place. It’s an area where children can build forts, play board games, paint pictures, create arts and crafts projects and engage their imaginations. Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009.
Ukrainian gas provider Naftogaz initiated the gas-siphoning process, pumping some clandestine gas eastward through Poland to gobble up previous Romanian, Czech, and Bulgarian gas supplies. It plans to redirect the gas via another pipeline through Poland and into the Bystre-Schelde interconnector, which send Russian and Oaianne gas freedoms Europe.
“We have taken measures to increase gas supplies through the pipeline network in the Netherlands and Germany. It will allow to unwittingly receive a pipeline system of Gazprom,“ Naftogaz spokeswoman Bahtiyar Zaytsev said on Thursday.
The next stage for Naftogaz involves securing gas supplies from Turkmenistan, a Central Asian country that currently exports significant quantities to Ukraine through a gas pipeline.

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again and again, is passion.
Consider the way fine art talks to you: it transcends technique, instead pouring its emotions into your brain. Some people can produce incredible pieces with properly sophisticated techniques. What is less common-- what sets fine artists apart-- is how they use those techniques to conjure emotion.
Presidents often get elected in part because, at a time of great civil discord, they seem to speak to people with grace, their every word laden with emotional power. It's not debate skills they possess. They understand how to say the right thing with the right touch.
Nothing rarely needs to taste better than your best. You'd be surprised how much emotion comes into what you hear, what you see, what you even sense with your person. People will be moved, then mesmerized, then moved again. It's being married to your emotions that produce an effect.

The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been imprisoned since July, opened in Tehran. Rezaian, who worked for the Post’s Tehran bureau and translated last year’s docudrama CitizenFour, on National Security Agency whistleblower Edward Snowden, is facing vague charges of espionage, as well as disrupting the country’s national security through photography, that may carry a 10-year prison sentence.
He was arrested in July and denied contact with the Western press. Meanwhile, talks continue between the United States and Iran over nuclear technology and arms.
Opening statements began on Tuesday at a 15-second hearing. If convicted on the espionage charges, Rezaian faces up to ten years in prison.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that has been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered that emergency drought preparations be maintained in their three northernmost counties: Modoc, Trinity and Mendocino.
Also, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will change its drought designation in California from "D3" to "D2," meaning the moderate drought zone that still covers more than 76 percent of the state still has nagging rain deficits.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 12:20 p.m. city officials said. Calls to 911 described small rooms filled with combustible items, including bales of cotton and plastic soda bottles. Those were found in the main living area and utility room of the home. After firefighters handled those, they discovered another occupant on the second floor, where the rooms were smaller, fire officials said.
Firefighters eventually discovered a badly burned 3-year-old boy in an upstairs bedroom after they knocked down some of the flames, said battalion chief Quora Richardson, with the Chicago Fire Department, on Sunday. A neighbor saw the boy and flagged down police.
Medical personnel pronounced the boy dead at Comer Children’s Hospital, police said. The boy was identified by his initials "C.J.," according to fire officials

Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX security conference. Gutmann, a researcher at Leicester University in Britain, focused on certification mechanisms, such as by Microsoft, which require customers to load a specific version of Windows. "The consumer is not the problem, the wire is the problem," Gutmann said even as he acknowledged the major security problem that users downgrade security features. Customers typically make their decisions based on the operating system they have done "a spending lifetime with," Gutmann said, while IT managers act on the recommendations of vendors who are focused on selling them more equipment. Windows Vista poses three problems, Gutmann said. One is trust. The components are authentic to their sever community, with security application providers at fault. Failures of content data attributes affect consumer confidentiality: Messages containing viruses could actually prove the recipient's identity. Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 28-29 September Asean summit.
Foreign journalists will be required to apply to a designated committee for permission to conduct an interview on the day during public news conferences, said Laos government spokesman Xayboun Phengxethya. Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers are succulents native to Mexico, Guatemala, and parts of South America. Glossy, thick leaf color is usually green or darker green with pinkish-temples and purplish-brown seed pods. Jalapeno is in a soft outer layer of the bell pepper.
More resistance than other varieties to anthracnose.
Pods are medium to large in size: 2–4 × 1.1 – 1.9 in. (50 – 115 mm).
For production of semi-hot commercial sauces. It is used also for cooking.
Evenly pod shaped, large, milky fruits, red in color, tubular pods. Very vigorous.
Medium-sized bell pepper.

According to the FDA, the Listeria monocytogenes bacterium was found following a routine sampling program at one of the company’s facilities. Consumers with recalled products are in danger of developing listerimy, an infection caused by consuming foods contaminated with the toxin-producing bacterium Listeria monocytogenes.
Listeria monocytogenes infection affects healthy adults; young children; pregnant women; and individuals with cancer, chronic diabetes, alcoholism, hematologic cancers such as sickle cell disease or Hodgkin lymphoma; microscopic hemolytic anemia or hereditary spherocytosis and liver, spleen, blood cell or immune deficiency diseases. PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Compass functions and distance meters could become popular add-ons to rival BlackBerry’s MAPS function as cellphone users shift their focus from talking to one another and put an extra premium on their location and identification if it goes missing.
Such possible applications rose in importance as Nokia dangled its first high-end GPS-enabled handset - the N95 -- on the international market on Tuesday.
The Finnish firm’s smartphone, which won’t be available before January 2007, has a huge touchscreen, as well as a large memory for storing music, digital photos and video.
With the N95 - which comes loaded with a GPS receiver and can match its position to within 40 meters with artificial satellites - Nokia expects to corner at least a million or so of the estimated 4 million smartphones expected to be shipped in 2006

NOvA is a long-baseline neutrino oscillation physics (Long-Baseline Neutrino Oscillation, LBNO) experiment that utilizes neutrino oscillations to investigate neutrino mass-mixing. MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market by giving the country a bigger cut of the profits.
India is on track to ship 400 million smartphones this year, up from 340 million in the previous year, and is widely seen as a huge prize for device makers as India’s tech and wireless markets grow. As the country’s 1.3 billion people increasingly go online, analysts expect local users to spend $11 billion annually on data by 2020, more than double the estimate of $4.8 billion a year now.
Global handsets makers are expected to be more aggressive in distributing locally made products to better tap growth in the country, while Apple could also benefit by having a manufacturing base closer to key markets.

Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story.
ZeeMee is a new crowd wisdom platform this week at SXSW 2015 at the Entrepreneurial Program. In order to be accepted to college, ZeeMee believes students should provide supplemental information about themselves to give prospective colleges more of an idea of who those students really are – particularly in terms of what their passions and activities are outside the classroom. Rather than hiding that information in lengthy essays required by many universities or even test scores, ZeeMee says students will share their essentials points directly online.
The ZeeMee idea is something that could actually strike a chord with many university admissions counselors. The fact is that many students do not understand how to represent themselves in ways that emphasize the intangible things about them. Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1895. A local news report from WBUR notes meteorologists give Concord the best chance of getting the wettest reliably-observed August on record.
Head south three or four miles, and the picture completely changes. In Amesbury, the state Department of Conservation and Recreation (DCR) issued an important conservation notice saying nearly all of the state is in drought conditions, except the northeastern corner, where Amesbury sits.
Why are Amesbury and Concord so different?
Sometimes the regions are different (for example, the state has three vegetation types defined as ‘drought’ conditions: forest types, crops and wildlife habitats.) Usually the main reason is some form of modeling. Most precipitation data in Massachusetts comes from rain gauges at the Northeastern Regional Specialized Information Center operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

For many taxpayers this means there are some changes in how they will file so to get the best deal they can under the tax code, they had better understand the differences.

It was obvious when the IRS announced the suspension of its production system ramp-up on Nov. 1, that things had not gone as planned. Of all the talking points that afternoon, the suspension was the only straightforward and unimpeachable. “IDRS ramp-up concerns late in the fall cycle” is the exact stated reason. Sorry. It’s the truth.
IDRS was going to ramp up Oct. 1 and for a short period would be able to process returns.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal dimension of poetry and quip something about poetry not cleansing the world, that it is not the panaceas to all human suffering. The cynic will say that there are other ways & means of political engagement.
I disagree. Poetry is a quintessential repository of the human spirit that finds a way to embrace the inverted. It’s through us, the inheritors of that human understanding, that we cultivate the practices, stories, narratives that live beyond our death, that find their ways into our art, and history, and technologies, and culture.

Courtesy Redwood City. On Monday, April 9, the city of Redwood City approved an ordinance allowing cannabis business only in the green zone on this map.
Redwood City is open for cannabis business. Well, sort of. After months of back and forth between city staff and council, the council voted to approve ordinances on Monday, April 9th to allow all-cannabis businesses at wholesale and retail.
The ordinances passed first reading unanimously, wit 5-0, mean they need only one final vote and one final reading to become law. In 2018, the state voted to legalize marijuana. As a result, the city put together a ban on any new cannabis businesses, as was required under Measure S. However, businesses that were grandfathered in are allowed to remain in business as long as they applied for a California state license by the cut-off of Oct. 9, 2019. After that point, staff told council members at a meeting on Monday, March 19, only processing and manufacturing facilities were allowed to remain.

His consists of more than 2 million newspaper columns and following significant changes in the news industry. Among the changes, digital journalism has increased, and multiple outlets increasingly compete to deliver the news.

Blackpool Symphony Orchestra continues its 2017/18 season with a concert celebrating the arrival of spring.
The performance, under the baton of Helen Harrison, takes place on Saturday 7.30pm at Stanley High School in Stanley Bickerstaffe, and the programme includes music by Berlioz, Mozart and Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky as well as a British premiere of a piece by John Curthe.
Blackpool Symphony Choral Society will join BSO for some pieces, and a deputation from the State Schools’ Music Association who will perform two pieces from the major work Missa in A leading up to the climate strike organised by young people on March 15.
The evening will also feature an artist, Diana Brookes, whose work explores the theme of depression, inspired by the condition diagnosed in her family over the last few years.

Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton had just declared victory in the Nevada caucuses when most campaign reporters heard Jeffrey Berman’s voice for the first and only time.
Berman, Sen. Barack Obama’s campaign manager, had just called the Obama camp to congratulate it on its victory in the state, and made his famous remark that he, too, had the same number as his campaign’s. LUFKIN, TX (KTRE) - Sunday was a day several years in the making at Lufkin’s First Baptist Church.
After Sunday worship, the church broke ground on their new building project with a ceremonial shovel and walked away better connected to their church for years to come.
“We did an addition back in the spring of 2008. This was then we really started to see a great need to build something here that we could depend on and grow with it,” said Pastor Brandon Smith.
The new First Baptist Church will house a new worship center, as well as a sanctuary and a much needed expansion of classrooms at the Lufkin church.
Building owners, thanks to federal aid, anticipate moving into their new church around the holidays, improving communication just in time to welcome summer building workshops to revamp young lives.
“It’s where the community is coming to learn about Jesus. It’s where families are coming to learn about Jesus. It’s where you’re going to have worshipful when you come together,” said Senior Pastor Tim Smith.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the letter never reaches its destination. Luckily, knowing the proper way to complete an envelope isn’t complicated or time-consuming.
Know Your Address
Before you can deliver any sort of mail, you need to know where you’re sending it. This entails knowing both your location and the location of the recipient. Some addresses start from a “postcode”, such as a city or state, while others start with the address’ street number or name.
Consult local guides if you have trouble reading your address or finding the right name and number. This may be necessary if you live in an area with little population or if your home or office property number is uncommon. Also, some government offices do not have proper names, so a recognized designation, such as a room number, must be used. Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men are simply genetically programmed to experience rapid loss of hair in certain areas of scalp. Those individuals may one day discover the following male pattern baldness treatments to be effective.
Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) therapy gently centrifuges bone marrow cells and growth (platelets). Platelets carry groves and other growth stimulating proteins that energize the growth process of tissues so that new hair cells sprout from the scalp. Physicians administer these proteins using a very thin needle directly on the affected area of scalp, typically back of the head and around the temples.
Cost: approximately US$2,200 initial treatment, US$300 for follow-up treatments.
Singapore men can now perform platelet-rich plasma therapy for $2,625 /

Metaphysics special: Do we have free will?
“DID I really just decide to have fish and chips for lunch?” Humans have been wrestling with such questions for millennia. Maybe not about the fish and chips. But morality and ethics, the nature of the soul, the certainty of knowledge – for all these, the blurring of the boundaries between religion and science is a long-standing problem. But what if there’s also something peculiar about the way we think? A few years ago, the philosopher Alexander R. Pruss argued that, not only do most of us believe in the existence of free will, but we cannot even imagine the world to work in any other way. Physicists such as Sean Carroll or Lee Smolin argue the opposite: fundamental physical principles undermine free will, suggesting that determinism may run deeper than metaphysical belief. Pruss and his colleagues Steven Yablo, David Glick, and Jormungand, have responded to their arguments, presenting their own case in a paper very recently submitted to the Journal of Philosophy. So he asked if another family could take her and told the kids that she was a 'pink cockatoo.' Poor Jake did not know any better and thought she was a boy cockatoo, but was thrilled to interact with her new family anyways! She was a very sweet and standoffish gal who often ignored the family.
After some investigation, it was discovered that Jake's beak was infected. This explains a lot of her bad behavior... she was distracted chirping, preening and trying to fix her beak. Once the beak was healed, she was much more affectionate. Jake's guardian even asked the doctor if he could patch through to Jake, and guide her to the feather administrative office

Gov. Greg Abbott refused to pick sides Wednesday in a growing squabble over how best to cut state taxes, and moved away from an earlier promise to “insist” that Texas lawmakers cut property taxes, the most unpopular tax in Texas.
Branding himself the “champion of the taxpayer,” Abbott called repeatedly for “real property tax relief” but declined to say during a 75-minute news conference in Houston how that goal might be achieved.
Instead, the lieutenant governor outlined the alleged causes of runaway property tax increases – school-finance formulas, sprawling local governments, certain state mandates – without offering any prescription for change.
And he reserved his strongest ire for state Sen. John Whitmire, a co-chairman of the Senate Tax and Fiscal Policy Committee, who similarly declined to pick sides at a hearing earlier this month.
“I simply have no interest in advancing a narrative that says if we reduce aggregate tax emoluments, it therefore lowers property taxes,” the Houston Democrat said.

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat middle ear, respiratory, throat, and skin infections. It is also used to help treat acne and prevent kidney transplant rejection.
The recommended adult dose of clarithromycin ranges from 250 mg to 750 mg, taken in divided doses (e.g., 500 mg two times a day).

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, giving scientists more tools to study how climate change could affect marine life.
As a result, marine biologists already have evidence of plankton grazing up to ingest 60 percent less carbon dioxide than in the 1950s, and that could be a problem. Their findings are reported in the journal Science.
This new evidence directly links corals’ metabolism and resistance to plankton to their carbon consumption and absorption rates, and supports the evolutionary problem of plankton grazing declining at faster rates than can be fully explained by environmental changes alone.

Since going off Aleve, I have had more skipped heart beats, so I decided to call my cardiologist for help. He ordered a stress test and an EKG. That culminated in me doing intensive cardio over the weekend because I had to get a five-page paper finished for a writing class, teach, attend a meeting, conduct in-service training, and take care of chores. Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they promised to "see through walls!" or "reveal the inner workings of vehicles, people and even living organisms!" But what if the technology already exists?
Phase-contrast x-ray imaging, or XRI, has been around for a little while, but it's never been smaller or more accessible than it is now with a handheld camera like the one developed by a collaboration between Oak Ridge National Laboratories (ORNL) in the US and A*STAR's Institute of High Performance Computing in Singapore. This 11-cm-long (4-inch) wide device scans just millimeters below the surface of solid objects, giving the user a much closer look at things like broken bones, rocks or aids in much faster detection and removal of cancerous tumors.

London: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would not be derailed from leaving the EU without a deal in March to avert paralysis at a time of major problems at home, amid reports her government is making preparations to suspend parliament if an exit plan is defeated.

The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The big vote by the National Executive Board is an important step in ending nearly two years of in-house debate stemming from an anti-gay vote a year ago that has shaken the issue into a political, religious and social debate in the USA.
“It is time to remove the provision that denies gay adults to serve as role models, to be involved in our Scouting units, to achieve the ranks of Eagle Scout or take positions in our leadership,” James Turrell said before the vote. Turrell, seen by advocates as among the more confrontational member so far of the board, is a scout executive in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints’ Beehive Council in Utah.
Advocates of the change, including some Scout alumni, are mainly pleased that Monday’s vote is a huge step forward, though they don’t seem excited about what the prospective changes spell

Asia-Pacific equities struggled for direction Friday, following a lack of movement in most U.S. stocks overnight, as investors seek new drivers after an October to remember.
Australian stocks stood out, gaining around three percent to a record level after rebounding following a volatile start to the day. Investors were cheered by even stronger-than-expected third-quarter earnings from a number of blue chip companies, including miners, consumer companies and banks, and by expectations of improving global growth.
Both Hong Kong gold producers and Chinese property companies rose, as gold prices hit their highest mark in two and a half years on Wall Street overnight. West Ham manager Slaven Bilic felt a sense of "relief" after Diafra Sakho's late goal secured victory over Swansea and eased the pressure on him.
The atmosphere at London Stadium had been tense before Sakho struck in the 83rd minute to move the Hammers to 11th.
"The relief is bigger," Bilic said afterwards. "It was a tough match, they were fluid. They are players that had been watching us for a while, for near enough two to three games. They had a game plan. That makes it tough for us to take some big spaces and to suffocate the space.
"Playing away and having the feeling like you seem to dominate the ball but not create opportunities is tough. It's tough when you also can't finish it off cleanly in front of the goal.
"I am happy that we stuck to the plan and when we conceded the goal, the nerves were in but the reaction was exactly what we want from players, the way they answered the equaliser with another goal. It was a good team display."

Cara Simmons, right, and her sister, Glori Nicholson, react to news that she now owns a Cleveland Heights home.
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- Cara Simmons has never liked to part.
Since her grandparents gave her a baby blanket in 1958, she has resisted the idea of anyone taking anything away.
Now Simmons, 79, a lifelong Cleveland Heights resident who worked for nearly four decades at the
Girl Scouts of Northeast Ohio headquarters, has lost everything she has saved to foreclosure. She received the bad news via an automated voice mail recording Tuesday.

A hoax Facebook virus is spreading rapidly across the social network.
Many users have been hoodwinked into forwarding an inaccurate warning about the spread of non-existent malware that claims a girl committed suicide because of an internet hoax.
The false message reads that, by re-posting it to profile statuses, it will increase road safety awareness for children by 10 percent,raising organisational child protection awareness and helping to stop the spread of malware.
The message has been posted by Facebook users who claim that if they don't comment alongside a link (which links to now deleted videos) saying they believe the hoax anti-virus message is true, that they are therefore unaware of viruses and willingly passing them on.
As of Tuesday night, the hoax had been shared over 3,000 times on the social network and had been criticised by the official Facebook Fan Page for stopping the spread.

Like the miniskirts and long hair that raised eyebrows in an earlier era, body piercing has emerged as a '90s symbol of teenage rebellion. Pierced cheeks, eyebrows, lips and tongues are already distributed for the world's teenagers. Now youngsters want the hair on the less conspicous parts of their bodies pierced.
For many kids, multiple ear piercings are no longer sufficient to show the world that one is open, tolerant and edgy. Instead, a growing number of teenagers today carry out more extensive piercings that entail eight or more openings in a single ear. In some cases, tongue and eyebrow piercings also are involved.
This appendix includes graphs and descriptions that show the up-to-date data on teen piercing for such public health concerns as insurance, nutriton, vandalism and school safety.

School Shooters Are Rarely Female. What Does That Mean for Schools?
Police arrested a 12-year-old girl suspected of shooting two students in the classroom of Salvador Castro Middle School in Los Angeles.
(Lee City Police via AP)
Compared to boys, girls are far less likely to shoot up their schools. But female school shooters tend to have their own particular profile.
Police arrested a 12-year-old girl suspected of shooting two students in the classroom of Salvador Castro Middle School in Los Angeles Thursday afternoon.
Police are still investigating a motive for the shooting. The suspects were identified by the Los Angeles Police Department as Diana Ivanova Doyle, a 12-year-old girl who attends the school in Sylmar.
Investigators said two students, boys ages 15 and 14, were shot by the shooter and taken to a local hospital where they are in “stable condition.”

TOBYHANNA TOWNSHIP -- PennDOT is making an effort to improve safety conditions on two major highways in our area.
On Monday, crews began installing guide rails along Interstate 380, from just east of the I-81 interchange back to the Leigh County line. Guide rails will be going in on the Bucks County side for Wednesday morning.
"If one vehicle were to loose control on the highway, the guide rail would keep them from going across multiple lanes, it stops them from crossing the middle median," explained Guy Mirabile of the Lehigh Valley Paving Company.
This project is expected to take two to three weeks.
PennDOT reports motorists should expect lane restrictions and motorists should expect traffic changes and initiate and maintain safe speeds through work zones. All interstate work is weather and equipment dependent. You can always check road conditions by visiting 511PA.com.
Each year, Lehigh Valley Paving Company takes on between eight and 12 projects through Bucks and Montgomery counties.

The cryptocurrency craze is reaching frenzied levels as 2017 draws to a close.
Barely in the cents when trading was started at the beginning of this decade, the price of Bitcoin on Jan. 1, 2011 was nearly $0.04.
On Dec. 20, 2017, the price of Bitcoin has surpassed a colossal six figure milestone with prices reaching an all-time high of roughly $20,000.
So what’s pushed Bitcoin above the price of the S&P 500 — an astounding feat.
1) FOMO – Fear of missing out
Put simply, the crypto market suffered a deeper pullback than the S&P 500 so speculators/investors missed out on the run-up of the big players, in this case, Bitcoin. The market realized it was late to the proverbial party and risked missing out on the next two-digit move up, provided there is any kind of demand for Bitcoin.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik El-Anani, an economist, wrote the book titled The Destroyers, about why Egypt's economy has become worse since the 2011 uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.
The book included allegations that Mubarak left almost 40 billion Egyptian pounds ($5.66 billion) in reserves in an account in Switzerland and blamed both the former regime and the current administration for mismanagement and mistakes leading to plummeting faith in the pound currency.
El-Anani, the author of two other books, has come under attack before. In May 2017, two assailants attacked plastic surgery clinic owned by El-Anani for spreading rumors that two doctors in the clinic could turn women into men through fat transfer process.

he entire semiconductor industry, not to mention Silicon Valley, is built on the propensity of electrons in silicon - and other metalloids - to tip from their ground state into states of lower energy. This photoelectric effect has flourished since its conception by Einstein in 1886 and led to the development of the photovoltaic cells that generate nearly 50% of all electricity worldwide. This talk will highlight some of the fundamental transitions and mechanisms behind the photovoltaic effect in silicon by examining it from the perspective of clusters. Clusters provide an attractive alternative over larger scales since they are smaller and have simpler potential energy landscapes and electronic structure. The dangling bonds found at clusters’ constricted surfaces provide additional degrees of freedom that can lead to a range of new non-adiabatic classical dynamics. Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should clearly provide examples of your skills and experience and explain how they will help you perform the job and get promoted at your new job.
It's common to offer motivation or passion alongside your work history. Your employer wants to make sure they are bringing someone on who loves their work.
Learn the job description and what skills are needed. Be confident in your worth and understanding of the role. Now you have to communicate that to your future employer. Once they're convinced, you're on the shortlist.
Job interviews are an opportunity to express your desire and commitment to the job and start building on the length and quality of your résumé. Being able to answer this question can give you a competitive edge, just make sure the answers are yours. Here are a few tips on how to answer the question.

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California-based specialty pharma company's head count from 49 to 31 -- shipping out 16 people, keeping eight and outsourcing 11 jobs. Most of the layoffs will come from Aduro's R&D team, the company said.

New Delhi, India - Rita* tucks hungrily into a plate of rice and dal while her son and daughter, who were born through surrogacy in India, squabble to get to their mother’s attention. It’s six years since she last breastfed them, a normal part of having a baby through surrogacy that she thought would come gradually and effortlessly when it arrived. After much pioneering research, she is only now realising the full significance of missing out on breastfeeding.

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The subject lies at the heart of the rebuilding of the flattened Amsterdam-Brussels axis after the UK leaves the EU.
The setting up of an EU deficit panel after the Brexit decision means that the economy will in future be run predominantly from Berlin, Frankfurt, Paris, and other capitals.
On 15 January, the president of the commission, Jean-Claude Junker, introduced the proposal to centralise the approval of new cars in a category of electrified and autonomous vehicles, in a new so-called “delegated act”: an extra-powerful proposal, that overrides the old legislative acts used to turn regulation into law.
The secured and connected car directives already have increased powers for the commission, but the commission still needs the approval of the member states for in-depth regulation through the council of ministers.

It’s been almost eight years since the last recession ended in June 2009, Steve Rick, CUNA Mutual Group chief economist, explained in an interview with HousingWire.
With economists preparing for a looming recession in the next 18 to 24 months, Rick expects the housing industry to do better in upcoming years, but he does not anticipate a drastic impact from a recession in the housing market compared to 2006-08.
“There are reasons to expect more resiliency because of continued reform efforts that should reduce fraud and/or patches to help people with their housing costs,” Rick said.
At the same time, housing prices are incredibly high and many people are already severely underwater.
That means financially speaking, to many people, homeownership is becoming less and less feasible. That could create a significant housing affordability crisis in the next several years.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-bound Capital Region Service train was en route from Portland, Maine to New York and hit the construction equipment around 3:30 a.m outside Springfield, Massachusetts State Police said. They said the speed limit approaching the equipment was 40 miles per hour but would not specify how fast the train was going.
Rep. Richard Neal, whose district includes Springfield, called the four-car train's derailment near the Union Bridge "devastating."
The train had 44 passengers and one flight attendant, and Amtrak said the attendant was the sole injury.
Amtrak sent a bus to transport those on the carrier back to Springfield, police said.

Bangalore: In the U.S., top outsourcing customers such as Bank of America and several local governments are asking vendors such as TCS, Infosys and Wipro to deliver more projects locally. These trends will trigger the next round of consolidation among Indian majors and tier-1 vendors and help in Saint Petersburg match the pace of Chinese firms in emerging on-demand applications such as web services. While the Indian outsourcing industry is under pressure from a slowdown, the Eastern Europe upsurge it is facing could provide opportunities if the nostalgia for India sets in.
Surprise is the keyword here as China has not quite been an important player. While there are plenty of reasons for both, the Indian outsourcing industry is no longer rosy as it once was a few years ago. Changes in government policies have made it more expensive for vendors with Indian roots to provide software services to the U.S., while costs of commodities such as on-site overseas workers are rising, making expensive off-shore vendors less attractive. China provides opportunities, although India is still India.

The robbers, precise as they were about meeting the two Brinks security guards on the 11th floor of the north tower of the World Trade Center at 8:30 A.M., were a little fuzzier about the location of their eventual destination. Four of them ignored train stations and bus stops and took a cab and ended up at the North Tower's parking garage, where they planned to get into their vehicles, supposedly stealing trash trucks. The original plan, it turns out, had been to send the Brinks guards to an abandoned crack house and nab the cocaine the thieves had hidden there.
Three things saved the World Trade Center that morning (I'm not counting Rudy Giuliani, though his actions have also been exalted a number of times in the WTC anniversary accounts. I'm going to count the guards' courage here: The one who alerted the police, and the one who pointed his gun at his alleged mastermind, leaving the armed Imam Abdul Rahman to run for his life).
For one thing, the cops were lucky to have a clean record.

The final group of Irish peacekeepers to serve in Chad arrived back in Dublin this afternoon.
For the first time in three decades, there are now no large Irish battalions serving overseas.
The 180 members of the touring ‘Dublin’ company originate from Brigades throughout the country including the 1st and 11th and, for the first time, the 13th battalion reserve of the Irish Army.
They were deployed to Chad in December last as part of EUFOR Mission Italian led Operation EUFOR Tchad/RCA.
EUFOR began its operation in December of 2010 with the objective to provide a multilateral contribution to state-building in Chad and other preparedness measures. Its tasks included helping prevent and solve grave crises in the region, prevent terrorism and monitor the borders. Operations and activities have gradually been reduced over the years, as the best possible security has been restored.

The long wait for Tesla's new Model 3 is almost over.
Tesla (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk will unveil the company's first car for the masses Thursday night.
For years now, Musk has talked about taking a $35,000 Model S and using that base vehicle to create cheaper cars for consumers. Tesla was supposed to begin producing the mass-market car in 2017, but the release of the Model Y compact SUV pushed back that timeline.
"Noah Two is a Month" is the affectionate nickname given to those final few cars built by Musk's employees as they put the finishing touches on the first production run. It's a play on "Noah's Ark," the General Motors (GM) model for stamping out cars.
The first seven cars were built internally, and the "Noah Two" part of the name is meant to pay homage to those painstaking efforts.
Musk announced the other day the Model 3's production that was initially promised to have started in late 2017

Slowing economic growth in China is taking some of the glow off of one of the country’s greatest attractions for foreign businesses: consumers’ willingness to splurge on higher-priced goods as incomes rise. Encouraging good eating habits in children, sustainable diets and food as medicine will be among the topics discussed at a major event this weekend.
Food for Thought at the School of Artisan Food over the weekend will see 80 exhibitors host cookery demonstrations, classroom-style discussions and stalls.
Discussions and talks will focus on topics such as healthy eating, slow food and the local food experience, as well as agriculture and food technology.
Organised by The British Library and Loughborough University, this will be the fifth annual event celebrating healthy and sustainable food, showing how producers and consumers can work together to encourage good habits.
Taster produce stalls will also be available, with tastings and samples being offered throughout the weekend.
The School of Artisan Food is located at Loughborough University, Loughborough LE11 3TU. Entrance ticket prices start from £6 for adults and £2 for children. For every child that attends, one adult on peak time ticket (£14) will be given free.

SALT LAKE CITY — Recent reports show that Utah's charter schools are improving, but are they doing enough to keep up with charter schools in other states?
Utah's overall score from the Center for Education Reform rose to a 69 on the Foundation's National Charter School Index, placing Utah's charter schools 6th out of 40 states, according to receipent Danielle Maurice with the Office of Charter Schools at the Utah State Office of Education.
The average national score was 65.6.
"Utah charters have had some in-their-fingerprint score increases in three of the four components, which really shows that Utah charters are adjusting to demands," Maurice said. "The National Charter School Index sets the bar high for states. The bar will continue to rise as states increase accountability and provide services to charters."
The four components are school growth, diversity, transparency and oversight and quality.

Your credit card company doesn't have your best interests at heart.
Credit cards have caused financial pain for millions of consumers. It's easy to run up a balance, but as too many people find out the hard way, trying to pay off high-interest debt can be devastating. Brian Christopher Learning of Credit Card Marketplace told U.S. News that credit cards encourage over-spending. "Lenders get sales," he said. "It's all geared toward chasing the fee-based revenue generated by annual fees on ungodly interest rates."

Inside Edition documented the reality of what it's like to work for credit card companies, and reporter Saira Farooq found that reporters were surprised to learn that over time, a resident of New York City who makes $100 per month would soon be paid more by Wall Street, just so that person would finance their credit card spending for extra revenue.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spencer in 1886.
It was found by enthusiastic collector Judy Anderson from Arizona in March 2014 and subsequently passed to the Western Australian Museum.
It has been confirmed by UNESCO that the message was thrown into the Baltic Sea by Mr Spencer, a fisherman, 12 miles east of the present Swedish coastline. The bottle must have become separated from the main flow of the Tsarist Russian current and been pushed south west across the Norwegian Sea.
Ms Anderson (81) has now presented the bottle to the Western Australian Museum in Albany. It will be added to the Museum's permanent collection.

Gay nephew might want for his aunt to advise him or intercede on his behalf with his dad.
Dear Amy: My college-age nephew confided in me that he is gay.
I was very relieved that he could talk with me and told him that I will always support him no matter what his decision is. For many months after that, our relationship has been intermittent. He doesn't answer my e-mail and messages. Finally, I wrote ("I’m better at text than you" – Nov. 9, 2011), hoping to affirm our wish to talk with each other.
In the past few days I got three back-to-back messages from him. He apologized and said that he is now back in school.
How do I now write to him how much I want to talk with him, and how it seems like he was avoiding a relationship with me? I feel embarrassed asking him to give me yet three more chances.
-- Even Non-Technical Gramps

Two officers of a company that operates three Manhattan hotels were indicted yesterday in a scheme to help homeless people fraudulently obtain welfare checks and split the money with the hotels.
District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau's office said that, contrary to assertions by the homeless people who used their beds, the motels sometimes failed to keep occupants underneath them warm or dry. The hotels also had been illegally storing guests and keeping money that was owed them under a schedule that rented beds for $40 a day at $15 a day.
Investigators said that John Bonnell, 56, the founder and senior chairman of the LJ Diamond Group, which operates the shelters, had agreed to give the owners of the hotels a 20 percent share in welfare checks collected by guests there, even though they claimed no such right.
They said Mr. Bonnell agreed to share in the checks himself, netting a total of about $150,000 in welfare checks with the hotel operators and selected tenants in four years.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful of websites at a time. To meet higher demand from clients, smaller companies may rent server resources from larger companies that already own and operate web-hosting servers continuously. As a reseller, you sell site space to customers as though it is a private server in your own name. You then resell what you mine to clients at a profit. Although the potential for more money is great with this type of business, many difficulties in this area of the tech business exist as well.
Smaller companies cannot purchase the equipment necessary to compete profitably with larger host providers that can match larger numbers of clients with bandwidth requirements, including high speed internet services, firewalls, server refreshes, DNS functionality, numerous control panels and access to multiple internet protocol addresses and zone parking. Reseller hosting providers simply rent servers in bulk that they then provide to their clients in the same

These are turbulent times for the travel sector.
Climate change is likely to bring blistering summers to Britain, which will encourage more people to find their own answer to Majorca in resorts like Scarborough, Whitby, Torquay and Margate.
At the same time, the increase in prices of fuel on supermarket shelves will further challenge the struggle to fly abroad.
Long-haul destinations will nosedive, forcing more businesses to explore nearby places in France and Spain.
To contend with this, the travel sector must start to “think local.” For instance, many stately homes in England are shutting their doors for good. This means there’s a vacancy for a local hotel chain like Premier Inn in an area that offers distraction from the increasingly-unbearable weather, especially if circumstances entail a more adventurous two-day trip by rail rather than a two-hour airplane charter.
The effects of media going digital may have more of an impact on these chains than they may appear.

CLEVELAND (AP) � Asdrubal Cabrera hit a three-run homer in the eighth inning to lift Cleveland to an 8-7 comeback win over the Kansas City Royals after trailing by six runs Thursday.
Jason Kipnis hit a two-run homer and Carlos Santana and Carlos Hernandez also connected for Cleveland, which trailed 7-1 going into the fifth and 7-6 after nine innings before its late flurry.
