The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Mortality Rate – or the number of babies who do not live to their first birthday – declined 2.2% annually between 2005 and 2014, from 6.45 to 4.81 deaths per 1,000 live births. In California, the Neonatal Mortality Rate from 2004 to 2013 fell 3.3% each year, from 4.91 to 3.86 deaths per 1,000 births.

The Public Service Commission on Wednesday approved a pilot program intended to create up to 350 megawatts of long-term renewable power within the next three years, a move that state officials and environmentalists say could help expedite North Carolina’s renewable-energy goal.
The Commission directed two now-closed coal-fired power plants in Rocky Mount to solicit renewable energy bids. The idea is to put the mothballed coal plant back into operation as a renewable generation facility, a move Public Service Chair Ed Starkey called critical as zero-carbon renewables face new competition from cheap fracking gas.
Now that the plants are no longer operational, North Carolina will have to backfill its coal plants’ 332 MW of generating capacity. Using the commission’s renewable energy credits, or RECs, the Rocky Mount units can be repowered as a wind project or solar plus storage facility or expanded to include solar storage.

What do Indy Mayor Joe Hogsett and Manual student have in common?
Jose Bravo was dressed neatly in a suit as he rode up the elevator to the 25th floor of the City-County Building. He sat opposite Indianapolis Mayor Joe Hogsett and wanted to show him a simple plea for change.
The mayor used big words to try to inspire the young New York native, including stressing the power in the young people. Bravo is a senior in high school, studying at Manual High School, one of Indianapolis’ best academics, athletics and arts schools. The mayor was a student in the arts himself, coming from a prestigious performing arts school, the Communications Workshop For The Arts.
These two were not at the governor’s desk or county commissioner’s office, but they were on the top floor of Indianapolis City Hall hand in hand, with Bravo’s passion for creativity, art and education and Hogsett’s desire for equality and telling the community’s voice for every citizen in his city.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “spindle cells” work on damaged DNA before it becomes dangerous. The discovery may help scientists learn more about cancer risk factors.
Researchers who discovered the protein PRDX1AW-FI described the elephant spindle cells as “pre-cancer cells.”
Because the cell was not found in a cancerous state or prevented an elephant from getting cancer, the researchers cautioned against applying zoology to human medicine.
That said, the find is important in another way, too: public health. Finding a new way to prevent cancer has been an elusive goal.
In 2011, the World Health Organization said some seven million people died of cancer globally, according to a 2017 estimate from the International Agency for Research on Cancer.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the Arizona State University Bob and Dolores Hope Center for Brain Health examined eight people in their 70s. All of them were overweight and had both hemorrhagic strokes and high blood pressure. Participants did one of three things: Complete yoga tasks for eight to 20 minutes, sit and relax for eight to 20 minutes, or perform iPad activities for eight to 20 minutes.
A cerebral-blood-flow imaging study showed activity visibly increased in the left and right mandibular regions, the tongue, the lower lip and throat and cerebrospinal fluid. Subjects who performed yoga tasks reported the highest flow activity in brain areas not associated with regular physical exercise.

New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces took voluntary disclosures from 20 large companies—energy producers, utilities and green power sellers responsible for about a fifth of the country’s greenhouse gas pollution—and crunched them to discover how risks to corporate profits from climate change, and the costs of new policies enshrining the Paris targets are “deliberately hidden in the footnotes”.
Market Forces campaigner Abby Gardner said the disclosures revealed 22 large Australian companies—including Origin, AGL and Snowy Hydro—seeking to meet the Paris targets they had just signed in concrete terms, and that was at risk of failing.
“Despite signing up to the Paris targets, which they acknowledge are necessary to stop dangerous climate change, these companies are not committing to transition plans that are clearly in line with what science actually demands,” she said.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. Early charts are irregular in time and are altogether brief, reflecting the nature of commerce and wealth in the northern seas. As commercial and other activities increased in the region, more detailed and exacting charts were produced. The frozen ice edge was an important feature of the Arctic, as it defined the northern limits to shipping that could drive through icebergs or sail up the arctic coasts of North America and Eurasia. The ACSYS Historical Ice Chart Archive presents historical ice observations in a standardized manner. The archive provides access to more than 375,000 free data records of ice edge positions as well as ice type and weather information. A user has the ability to interactively plot ships and their voyage

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemicals at a time when they cost more and have become a rarer commodity. It helps with water conservation, a time-honored value in arid climates. In urban and suburban settings, it often reorients backyard culture toward the healthy and spiritually lush. Finally, it is a culturally resonant and enriching value that builds community in the midst of a fast-changing urban environment.
While the composting infrastructure in New York City is nothing to write home about (in fact, keep reading about it), Community Compost will bring the best practices from so many great compost programs around the country to the old, stagnant system. It is nothing new, except for a little grassroots spoiling to give it the right mix of ingredients to work.

Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. If you aren't tracking your money properly, for example, you might inadvertently overlook discrepancies or other symptoms of irregularity or fraud. Your Purchase to Pay (P2P) group plays a critical role in this area, using lean methodologies to handle transactions. Once you apply lean accounting, you won't be able to imagine how you managed without the practice.
What is lean accounting?
At the supply chain management level, financial operations are organized into five primary processes: inventory management, purchasing, expense management, service and asset accounting. In traditional P2P applications, these operations are typically managed and analyzed separately or even combined without much thought itself.

Take 5: How can we stop being jerky customers?
The customer may not always be right. What are some circumstances where they could be wrong?
In a recent trip to a grocery store, I grabbed a few items on the shelf. Actually, I dropped a few items on the shelf and stepped on them. When I tried to have them returned to the shelf from which I picked them up by a pleasant older gentleman, he refused to give me another bent one. "They don't put the old ones onto the shelf to be picked up again," he informed me. "Customers are stupid!"
I realized with a shock that he was right because I am stupid. It took me a moment to recover myself and return a pleasant reply and not to say something unpleasant.
What do you think of the old "don't put a good one back" policy? Is it justified? Would you have taken him to task for being rude? (Inquiring minds want to know––and so do 42% of Americans.)
Posted by Marc Scott-Cowell on April 26, 2011

Odds are you've watched your favorite show on Netflix enough times to pick up on the overarching plot no matter what episode you're watching. Of course, you can manually choose an episode at "random," but the show will always resample from the plot creators' sequential list, essentially teleporting back to the beginning of the plot every time you hit "play." Netflix needs a smarter algorithm that learns more about you and what you want, and that's where our convolutional neural network (CNN) comes in!
A dataset containing the entire Netflix movie catalog is too expensive or difficult to procure, so to simulate tagging movies with the ratings of some users, we must simulate a distribution for our dataset. The dataset stays the same, however, the order in which we give the input to the network could be different every time. This constitutes a data distribution over the input vector that could range in length from 0 to a maximum of 40,000. "Country Music Hair" author Erin Duvall breaks down the 'dos.
You can't think about country music without thinking about hair. Whenever anyone talks about Dolly Parton, her look is mentioned in the first sentence. You can’t think about the history of country music, or its future, without considering the history of its hair, both high-glamour and gloriously natural.
There is a history to country-music hair: It began with cowboys (who, back in the day, had fantastically wild and woolly hats that hung over their eyes) and also Carrie Underwood (oh God, her hair). The genre itself is set apart by style and formula: think veils, things with bows and fringe, looks that move around like Cinderella’s dress. This should not surprise us: the nature of country singing, that most of it is about a desire to escape, means that hair serves as a physical and mental distraction.
One unhappy way country star’s hair works is that, most times, it is a distraction from its performers’ lack of boundary, vulnerability, and expression

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., his son Luke Karnow said.
Karnow's massive biography of the Vietnam War, Vietnam: A History, was published in 1983. It served as the companion book to the documentary. Both earned him a prestigious National Book Award the next year. More and more he became known for immersing himself into the places he wrote about, traveling to Vietnam in 1962, for instance, just two years after leaving Vietnamese refugees crowded around the airport after the Fall of Saigon.

Borneo, which holds the Malaysian states of Sabah and Sarawak, and is just a stone’s throw away … physically, culturally and linguistically from Brunei, being unique in the schism of hundreds of fragmented ethnic groups divided on both borders, Malaysian and Indonesian, brings a different set of values and customs. Batu Api is the name commonly used for the native dances performed at weddings. It is a vibrant and exciting ritual that is still practiced by many Malaysian villages.
The dance is adapted from Chinese New Year festivals in Malaysian towns and villages. In the Reunion Dances ceremony, the village women are dressed up to celebrate peace with the balance of the kinship of the young and old. The women serve as the village’s power structure and are used to enhance or initiate dances to signify inner spirit. Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify which options, or the methods behind those options, are most effective at achieving a certain end objective – much like a flowchart, information chart or hierarchy chart display the exact steps to a logical outcome. In simple terms, the diagram's branches can be read as a "what if" scenario based on a certain solution taken in the next few steps of the overall process: The right decision tree provides valuable insight for any small business owner, with a minimal learning curve.
Because the decision tree diagrams do not have set templates for formats or layout guidelines, developing one can involve trial and error. Branches show the different possible outcomes depending on the answers provided by those who will be using the diagram, removing any guesswork from future decision making, and the decisions themselves are the driving forces behind the outcomes. Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered down a mountain in Hkamti, Sagaing region, on Thursday, leaving about 40 people feared underneath.
Rescue teams pulled 20 people out alive after the disaster, all but one still missing almost two days later.
According to a police statement released early on Sunday, the search was called off on Saturday night because the mass underneath was so large and treacherous that rescuers were no longer able to extract survivors.
Even with excavators and heavy machinery, the resulting wind caused further debris to cartwheel down, the military warned.
A group from Myanmar’s manganese mining company, Asian World, said in a statement it withdrew because of the risks to rescuers and the need to conserve equipment as the violent rain continued.

Taipei, July 18 (CNA) U.S.-based search engine giant Google on Wednesday launched a new Google Maps service for motorbike riders in Taiwan that will help them plan their routes and calculate their journey times on the move.
The service can be accessed via the Google Maps Taiwan website, Google Maps mobile website, Google Maps mobile applications for the Android and iOS platforms and Indonesia’s Go-Jek instant personal transport application.
When a rider taps a chosen point on the map, the application specifies the best route to take for the following day or a set interval, the company said in a statement.
The company said that in addition to the dynamically changing routes and one-click sharing via the Facebook and WhatsApp messengers, the service provides important information on bus stops, photo shops, petrol stations and convenience stores to its users.
The service is based on Google’s location on demand platform and is driven by machine learning, the company said.

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot tempers.
The study, published this week in the Journal of Marriage and Family, compared 75 grandmothers who spent an evening in their grandchildren’s homes with another group of 75 grandmothers who spent an evening in another location. Their temperamental dispositions were assessed with a commonly used questionnaire that equates hot and cold dispositions as ‘aggression’ and ‘compassionate nodding.’
Results found that participating in the familiar setting had a relaxing effect on some subjects. More than half of the grandmothers who were spending time with their grandchildren scored significantly lower on hot dispositions following the evening than before. This reduction in hot disposition means that they were less likely to ‘win an argument over a purse or a husband’ — that is, they were more likely to hold back while playing games (or, compassionately nod) rather than becoming instantly angry.

Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive. The company recently completed its goals for the initial Stinger project, on which it began work in 2011. The company is now focusing on the improvements it made while maintaining efficiency and performance.
Historically Hive users have been frustrated that, as the job gets more complex, the job's performance degrades. Without parallelizing this performance begins to degrade exponentially with each task completed. Stinger.next takes some of the most complex and demanding tasks that must be performed before a query can be answered, and parallelizes those tasks. This gives more tasks to run simultaneously so many times the job's performance does not degrade with inquiry complexity. In other words, the parallelization done in Stinger.next works for all inquiries, whereas there has been no parallelization of tasks for simple inquiries that performed all of the necessary work on their owns to process the job.
A query applies when data for an insert is fetched even when the job had not yet applied the most recent one. Stinger.

The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 with the Family and Medical Insurance Leave (FMLA). The California Family Rights Act (CFRA) is also in place so that employees can have entitlement to family leave.
California’s paid family leave law provides fully paid job-protected leave to care for a new child or a seriously ill child, spouse, parent, parent-in-law, grandparent, grandchild, domestic partner, or a registered domestic partner. FMLA is unpaid, while FSLA requires paid leave for workers who have fulfilled minimum hours per year requirement.
In California, FMLA is also called California Family Rights Act. This FSL is a law of California that closely adheres to Family and Medical Act of 1993 laws. On October 30, a major new report on the impact of Marcellus Shale gas development on water resources will be issued. Water Resource Reporting and Water Footprint from Marcellus Shale Development in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, prepared by Virginia Tech economist Alex Farrell, with Amanda Daubert, Brian Halpin and Kyle Ferrar. The report examines water use associated with hydraulic fracturing and explores the question of whether those pumping interests impinge on the rights of local communities to use a key natural resource. For the past two years, the Marcellus Shale Safe Drilling Initiative team has searched for studies on water resources issues related to drilling for shale gas in the Marcellus Shale and has looked at studies that produce information beneficial to landowners trying to understand the impacts on their ground water resources. This 60-page report includes a comprehensive scope and fact sheet on water characteristics in the Marcellus Shale; an overview of the most common types of water withdrawals in that region and other basins, and the Stochastic model of municipal uses.

Remember Microsoft's Bing Cashback program, which refunded a few percentage points (and sometimes more than a few) of online purchases made via the Bing portal? Microsoft shuttered the program last June, but its echo remains. Then there was GPTrain, a 2016 program from Google that paid users for taking part in Google experiments. Now that, too, is gone.

Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. From April 15, Sunrise will enter a 6-month lock-in period which bars the Toswater Management fund from reducing its stake below 40 percent in the telecommunications firm.

Why is Christmas pagan and what is an alternative tradition to Christmas one can do instead? originally appeared on Quora: the place to gain and share knowledge, empowering people to learn from others and better understand the world.
Why is Christmas pagan, and what is an alternative tradition to Christmas one can do instead?
In The Origins of Christmas, John Butt presents some compelling evidence that the origins of the annual Christmas celebration evolved during the Dark Ages among regional Germanic groups of the West during what is often termed the Medieval Period. Butt argues many modern traditions derive from these regional festivals during that time because these feasts were transported to Britain by those who emigrated from continental Europe as part of the September 1972 Enoch mission -- a bold plan by the Office for National Statistics which sought to fulfill census requirements of the time by dividing the population amongst several colonies. Some researchers state the colonists traced the celebration from the day the mission begun, hence the December 25 date for Christmas.

A bizarre interstellar object called 'Oumuamua continues to perplex astronomers a year after it vanished. Here's why a few scientists still wonder if it was alien.
An illustration of an interstellar object passing close to — and possibly even diving into — the solar system. Matson Museum
Astronomers are trying to determine whether an interstellar object called ‘Oumuamua was made from a kind of “dirty snowball” or a metallic reflective soccer ball.
Their study found that interstellar objects may have a more varied mixture of what you might imagine. The objects may be a mix of icy snows and metallic rubble that’s common in the youngest corner of the galaxy.
Interstellar interlopers are a tricky thing to study. They’re on the move, they are too small to be observed in detail, and they appear to be natural objects, so they are too small or sparse for telescopes to (so far) catch them in the act of creating a strong hint of radio or light emissions. Warehouse retail king Costco recently ended its relationship with American Express in favor of a new one with Visa and Citigroup. And after a bit of a bumpy start, it looks like the new deal is starting to work. Today Costco e-mailed out a message to shoppers that it is offering the ability to sign up for its new Costco credit card, which comes with a 2 percent reward and all the perks that people are used to with the Costco credit cards.
That said, the messaging that Costco is sending out today shouldn’t come as that big of a surprise. The migration to a new card and credit card processors was certainly implied when Costco moved its United Kingdom stores to Visa and MasterCard in February.
The biggest drawback right now with signing up for the card is that it doesn’t allow you to withdraw cash at Costco yet. Costco is still testing the ability to accept Amex and the AT&T Corp. at its stores as an experimental extra credit card option with the goal of rolling the cash-out option out by 2017.

The move comes two days after Dawn Sturgess died from picking up a counterfeit version of the World War Two Czechoslovakian explosive.
Police said British citizens must be cautious because weapons designed only for military use can lead to “immediate death”.
They told people not to pick up guns, grenades, knives, daggers, bullets or decorative shells.

Cameroon’s Anglophone crisis, which started with strikes by teachers, students and those in the legal profession in late 2016 and now includes groups calling for secession, is deepening. People from English-speaking regions in the country’s Northwest and Southwest regions have organised under banners such as the South West Self-Defence Force (SWSDF), the South West Resistance Council (SWRC) and the North West Restoration Council (NWRC). A gaping socio-economic divide has changed perceptions of what it means to be earmarked as English-speaking. According to a report issued by the Pew Research Center, American adults have a sub-par knowledge of basic science. The organization surveyed 3,278 Americans of various social, racial and academic backgrounds. The questionnaire targeted US citizens’ knowledge of the world, and understanding of various sciences. Overall, the survey suggested that most people know very little. This isn’t shocking, since science has been dropping in schools for quite some time. A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had stopped in Seattle earlier for a quick refuel after taking off from Bellingham, Washington, for a trip to Los Angeles international Airport.
It was about 11 kilometers before the landing when Flight 579 had to return to the airport after the freighter caught fire and the airport got the alarm, Alaska Airlines said.
Workers heard loud noises and feared there was a fire in the belly of the huge cargo plane.
They went to go check out the problem and looked down and saw the airport personnel worker asleep, according to a state news bulletin.
It apparently had been a very long shift for the employee.
The airport is extremely large and the worker passed out for a brief nap, which explains why the worker did not hear the freighter engine cranking up to go.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of scam tactics during tax season each of the past four years.
How to go through your computer files. When it’s tax time, go through your financial files on your computer to look for evidence of fraud, including any email spam or phishing attacks. Keep an eye out for identity theft and other cyberactivity.
How to contact the IRS. The IRS has a dedicated cybersecurity promotion page. If you feel you may have fallen victim to a phishing scam, follow the directions on the IRS website to report the attack. It’s also important to know taxpayers have been protected from being responsible for some telephone fraud, so don’t panic if a call seems suspicious.

The Office of Multicultural Affairs facilitates the Navigation mentoring program that pairs students with a faculty or staff member who will serve as their Navigation Partner throughout their journey at the University of Dayton. Bias Related Incidents
We encourage students to report bias incidents that have occurred on campus or have impacted fellow students in a significant way. Please fill out and submit the bias incident report form to the Office of Multicultural Affairs or directly to BiasIncidents@udayton.edu.
Though students with marginalized backgrounds are often insightful on campus due to their experiences, the Office of Multicultural Affairs recognizes that they often face unique hardships in addition to their academic experiences. Students may contact Jasi'a Williams, academic advisor to students with marginalized identities, during each student's New Student Orientation experience or after. In addition, they are encouraged to contact the Office of Multicultural Affairs, who will connect them to campus supports.

There is no easy option for Northern Ireland after Brexit.
Deciding on post-Brexit border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic is becoming an issue for which the phrase "the devil is in the detail" could have been invented.
On a number of occasions US President Donald Trump has expressed strong opposition to anything that might potentially reduce economic relations between the United States and the European Union, including the open borders that exist between Ireland and Northern Ireland.
And while it is possible, perhaps inevitable, that the leadership of the UK, Ireland, and the EU will be determined to go all-out in pursuing an agreement with President Trump, it will by no means be straightforward to construct practical border functions that can reflect the political will of the three parties.
The government's preferred option would appear to be a free trade area with the UK but maintain a customs border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, with Northern Ireland following EU rules during British negotiations. This option was known as "backstop" before being released, and had been the see-through option.
It seems to have been rebranded as "landbridge" as details outlining the mechanics of the mechanism

Many in the media and tech industry see Uber’s decision to sell its Chinese business unit to rival Didi Chuxing as a failure for the U.S. ride-hailing giant. It’s easy to believe that analysis, given the publicized struggles of other high-profile giants of the digital economy in its attempts to carve out a large digital pie in China. But there is a very different cause underlying the struggles of high-profile tech firms that do not operate in China, namely that the Chinese cyberspace is the most uncompetitive global arena for tech companies outside of the advanced economies. When compared with countries like China, India, South Korea, the United States or Europe, the United Kingdom does not so much have a reputation as an innovator or a global digital economic power on account of the success or relative failure of leading tech companies based there. It has almost no reputation as a supra-national location for tech companies, despite the emergence of UK-licensed innovators for its economy. Insight: Did Conficker help sabotage Iran's nuke program?
(Reuters) - A cyber warfare expert claims he has linked the Stuxnet computer virus that attacked Iran’s nuclear program in 2010 to a cat-and-mouse battle in the late 1980s between the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) and a mysterious group with ties to the Soviet Union.
The most potent computer virus of its kind, which was designed to target centrifuges in Iran, has been cited by real-world security researchers and U.S. President Barack Obama as a harbinger of future possible cyberattacks on systems that run public and private utilities and systems.
The argument hinges on the possibility that Conficker, the Microsoft Windows root kit found to have infected more than 1.4 million computers a year ago, may have been the match: It was designed years in advance, allegedly by the Israelis, to disable and degrade machines running the Industrial Control System (ICS), a subgroup of systems that also would have run Stuxnet

Khairuldeen Makhzoomi, 26, is a senior at University of California Berkeley. Makhzoomi lives with his mother and younger brother in Oakland. His father was an Iraqi diplomat whom Saddam Hussein executed after his capture in 1991. Years later, Hussein’s oldest son, Qusay, put Khairuldeen’s mother on a list to assassinate. Qusay was also killed by coalition forces in 2003.
Khairuldeen’s mother said her oldest son “has a different experience than most children in this country.” “He, like many of my students, finds it hard to merge two cultures and he also finds it hard to explain the suffering and the civil war that happened in Iraq, and why something positive has not come out of it.” Khairuldeen's mother is "incredibly proud that he is able to speak his native language, a language that he loves because it represents a peaceful place to a very violent man (Saddam Hussein)."

It may be cheaper than driving, but commuting by public transport can still be pretty pricey.
Commuting to work via public transportation is usually cheaper than driving everywhere.
But in these major cities, a monthly pass is pricier than a yearly registration for the same type of transportation.
The biggest and worst are in big countries, such as India and Brazil.
When a busdriver in Delhi — the most populous city in India — commutes 35 kilometers (22 miles)
a day, he's paid a salary of only $1,476 a year.
In Brazil, people who commute by train or bus save money, but only because they pay more per ride.

Growing up on Chicago’s North Side, “Rocky” Yamanaka recalled few incidents of racism. “Me and my sister were the only Japanese. But we were curiosities to most of the Caucasian kids,” he said.
Events prior to his mid-teen years changed that and he experienced a new awareness from both sides of the street.
“I remember getting jumped my first year in high school. Most people thought I was going to cry or cower because I was so scared that night,” he said. “I stood my ground and threw a roundhouse. This upset the boys a bit, so they decided to have a name for me. I remember walking away, hearing one of the boys yell out Poop Yemanaka,” he said, explaining that the name was a combination of his behavior and someone’s childhood pet dog.
Yamanaka traipsed home, shaken, that night. “My mom and dad were devastated because they never, ever heard the Japanese spoken in an negative or degrading way,” he said.

Surgeon Michael Stern, M.D., and Matthias Friedrich, Ph.D., researchers at the Wilmer Eye Institute at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore, Peralta found that a keto diet was linked to lower eye pressure over the long term, which could protect them against disease later in life.
The study, published in January 2018 the journal JAMA Ophthalmology, looked at 200 participants from an ongoing trial. Participants had their eye pressure, a possible marker for open-angle glaucoma, measured for two years. MANCHESTER UNITED star Michael Carrick has revealed a heart scare has limited his game time this season.
The Old Trafford skipper has not featured for the Red Devils since September and has released a statement on his future.
“I’ve been ruled out of the rest of the season and have some tests to complete before a final view is determined,” Carrick said in a club statement. “They are quite specialists in heart conditions really so hopefully I can prove that I can come back to play, not before too long but at some point next season.”
The 33-year-old, who will miss England’s World Cup qualifiers with Slovakia and Scotland in March has maintained his fitness and believes he will return to the first team.
“I hope to strengthen the squad next season, that’s for sure,” continued Carrick. “We get the FA Cup final up and running on Sunday if we can get over Bayern Munchen which will be a challenge and maybe get a fitness a run into that game.”

Later he said his ankle had 'gone': you sense Anderson wouldn't have missed all those set-pieces if he hadn't.

September 3, 2014: The ferocity with which some Western (and nearly all Arab) military analysts attack Israeli efforts to defend themselves is remarkable, and often spectacularly wrong. Even Israeli systems, while providing robust defense are not perfect, and many of those efforts to defend themselves deserve caution and critique from outside actors only with the cold-eyed distance of people who no longer have their lives at risk to defend their country. Too often, their efforts are attacked by people who live many miles away, often in a country that itself is a systemic human rights abuser and that denigrates Western values on many occasions.

The most vitriolic and absurd examples of them have some telling features in common. NEW YORK — For a second year in a row, the NFL will air a dramatic PSA during the Super Bowl addressing the issue of domestic violence.
This year’s video shows a succession of text messages between two friends — one of whom has been working up the nerve to end an abusive relationship. As with last year’s ad, the narrator — Good Morning America‘s Robin Roberts — is moved to tears as she relates the profound impact of what has been going on behind closed doors.
Domestic violence prevention agencies had yet to universally speak out over whether the NFL’s efforts should be expanded into its headquarters in suburban Eagan, Minnesota, however those with knowledge of the NFL’s discussions on the subject said recently that any similar message would have to come from the top of the league.
It’s not clear if the NFL asked for the full cost in return for the proposal, but a source familiar with the discussions said the league was willing to “be flexible” in its approach with several agencies.

Two days after millions of women and their allies throughout the world celebrated the inauguration of the first U.S. president elected by women, Michael H. Mukasey, the U.S. attorney general, quietly set in motion a step intended to limit American tax dollars in faraway countries from being spent by international nonprofit organizations that perform or counsel about abortion-related activities.
The purely staunchly antiabortion step, dubbed by longtime critics the “Global Gag Rule,” prohibits the use of federal foreign national-aid funds for programs or products that give information about abortion, refer women in other countries to other services to obtain an abortion, advocate abortion or use foreign government funding that may have been used in part for abortions.

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident life.
Such types of events are rare – as astronomers have only observed a handful of supernova events in the last decade. And even more uncommon are the instances when those same events are perceived by Earth-bound observers during their most vibrant phase, also known as the velocity component of the event, known as maximum light.
When viewed from our planet, however, one such supernova exploded nearby about 500 million years ago. The supernova event, named SNR 0516+1457 – pronounced "SNR fiveteen plus Fox Fourteen Five Seven" – was spotted first with plans to observe it again within the next 72 hours by scientists.

RIO DE JANEIRO (Reuters) - A weightlifter who lost his family's house in a cyclone danced off stage at the Rio Olympics on Tuesday to raise awareness of the rebuilding effort.
Shawn Matthias helped pay off his mother's mortgage after their house was destroyed in Cyclone Pam in the Solomon Islands in March, 2015, he wrote on his Vimeo account.
As he hopped onto the stage of Rio's Saudade Arena, Matthias' loud music -- which sounded similar to Kanye West's track "Power" -- ended. In the crowd, supportive shouts of "Matty ... Fight on!" rang out.
Matty had a powerful grip, confidently hoisting 115 kilograms (223.75 pounds) over his head as he made a giant sword and shield sign to signal roughly the time of year their house was destroyed.

Idealists like to say that money doesn’t decide elections, but the truth is, it usually does, said Don Dugi, a political scientist at Transylvania University in Lexington.
This isn’t news to politicos, but the public is beginning to wake up to what might be portrayed as their ignorance on the subject.
Thanks to a team of researchers publishing a book “Giving Blind?: Disposing of Campaign Contributions by State Officials,” the public is beginning to pull back the curtain on contributor funding. Co-edited by Transylvania ethics professor and political science instructor Blake Marshall, the book’s essayists plunged into the topic, mapping it down to individual voter tastes.
With Marshall looking on, the authors revealed a seamy underbelly that accompanies government officials’ acceptance of campaign donations. It could seem that every elected official in every state by now has accepted a donation and cashed it in for an interview, favorable treatment of a constituent, or the promise of public funding. It’s how our system is rigged.

MARIEMONT – Construction has begun on an addition at Mariemont Village Hall to include a shoe-box-sized Native American Cultural Center for a cost of about $3 million.

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers said they calculated that a single sheet of the device distributed over 100 square meters of ground (about the size of a tennis court) could generate sufficient power to meet all the electricity demands of an average U.S. household for about three months—if the snowfall hits 70 centimeters in a 138-square-foot area and is about 10 degrees Celsius. That may not sound like a lot of electricity, but the three-person team estimates that one-tenth of what falls as snow in California could power an entire village.
One big limitation: the device is only about 95 percent efficient at converting the potential energy from snowfall into electricity. It would need to be much more efficient, about 86 to 88 percent. That's why the researchers are tackling the problem on a very fundamental level: they say they've identified the way that snow creates electricity

So you're renting a car? It's no big deal, unless something goes wrong. Here's a checklist based on our own experiences and on the rental cars we've seen in our shop lately.
Get Insurance before you leave home
If, for some reason, you don't have insurance at home, go online and find out about what is available in country you will go That only takes a minute or two and is a very stream-lined and easy process. You can get insurance to cover full expenses or greatly lessen any deductibles One solution is to pay for insurance on rental days and get a part of the refund, get insurance for the complete rental period and get the whole amount back from the reimbursement of the deductible. It's all up to you to decide the type of insurance you will get.
The recovery key

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different shapes into the bark with crayons and lipstick. My dad used to draw a lot and my nan was always in art class: she used to collect bent wire and cassette cases and would put them in scrapbooks; she’s written a short story. I've always been drawn to people who make things, and as I got older I started trying more challenging things. My sister used to do some body piercing and she'd often get eight packets of cartridge needles to go and do ear piercings for fun. I'd try to be as weird as her.

When Rick Gates turned against his former boss, he described a parallel ethical universe where lying and cheating were as comfortable as a well-tailored ostrich suit.
You know what would be surprising? If Rick Gates had told the truth.
His appearance at Trump Tower was no surprise. After all, it wasn’t his first. The interesting part was simply that he finally decided to reveal what he’d been hiding for months. Anyone would have thought that after asking Gates to bring documents and computer equipment to the White House for questioning and having him lied the way he did, Mueller’s team would have immediately recognized the nature of the engagement and bolted. After all, they were after the truth, not actors.
Actors in political show trials are nothing new. Pretending to be legitimate government officials and lying about criminal activity have been American staples since the 1750s. In that period, members of the Sons of Liberty (only “sons” in that they wanted children thrown into harbors instead of burning family businesses) dressed as British soldiers. At one point during an episode of the CW's mystery series Cult, one of the characters makes another the impassioned promise that "There will be an answer!" Given the show's intense love affair with metafiction, it's slightly apropos that they use the ostensible producer's name to create variations on the Gertrude Stein poetic logic, "There is no answer, there are numbers, numbers are. Cadence, the raven croaks." As Cult enters its final four episodes, however, I'm less concerned with Cult devotees' allegiance to the sparse poetry and more intrigued by how their level of devotion has masterfully managed to mirror the arrangement of certain fandoms' most important figures.
One of the many bitter pill aspects of the "mysteries" theme used for every other "creative murder mystery" show, Facetime and its ilk, is how they all mirror much the same tale out of Greek mythology, that of the human-god hybrid that, invariably enough, after coming into contact with the human plane, ends up falling victim to a set of shared fates between their more terrestrial peers

Potsdam, Germany-(ENEWSPF)- An international team of astronomers led by Dr. Andrea Kunder of the Leibniz Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam (AIP) in Germany and Dr. Raffaele Grimaldo of Cambridge University/ Cambridge Optical-Astronomical Observatory, Cambridge, UK, announced today the first direct detection of warm carbon monoxide (CO), a chemical mixture with sunlight. These results lend theoretical insight into planetary cloud formation, as suggested by planetary geologists, as well as chemical interaction mechanisms at the heart of solar system dynamics.
It is commonly known that certain molecules on Earth can create smog, particularly on hot days. However, because the sun’s rays are not strong enough to create enough heat such that these chemical reactions on Earth can take place, the non-amalgamated creation of such chemicals has been considered nothing more than their emission from Earth’s surface temperatures. Until now, this reaction had been unknown in space due to the lack of strong sources in their adversity.

The President’s bill offered a massive network of investment and consumer programs across several different government departments, ranging in scope and cost to the tune of $150 billion. Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle argued angrily over the detail and implications of the measure, and in a Senate that can often get polarized over parts of speeches dealing with the weather in the local paper, the vote pointed up some extraordinary schisms in the relationship between the White House and the legislative branch.

The Amici Singers and the Ensemble of Friends held a Remembrance Day concert at St Mary’s Church, Potton, in commemoration of the end of the First World War, presented by Douglas Coombes MBE, director of the groups. The event was in aid of the RBL, the Poppy Appeal and other veterans’ charities.
There was a wide and varied programme by both groups, including oratorios and motets for double choir, anthems for choir and soloists, motets for unison voices and a brass quintet.
Tony Lewis gave a talk from the newly discovered War Diaries kept by a local man, George Sessions Payne, who tragically died at Mons. The morning was rounded off with an evensong for Remembrance Day at 6 pm, sung by both ensembles.
The proceeds of the evening went to several worthy causes, including St Mary’s Church, the Royal British Legion, the Poppy Appeal and other veterans’ charities.

Regulators often struggle to keep up with the rapid pace of new technologies which hurts businesses and consumers.
Whether it’s a cutting-edge gadget, an exciting software platform, or an advanced app store, logistics, telecommunications and financial operators all need effective ways to launch their new products.
To accelerate the introduction of new products, mobile tech innovators and business models now need to navigate not only the marketplace but a complex, ever-changing regulatory environment too. Consensus is that this complexity isn’t just hampering markets but risking them collapsing.
TLG-CG and similar European and American efforts to answer this challenge are introducing, however, several mechanisms that seek to support regulators in coping with challenges such as ensuring choice and competition with lower overall costs as a result.

Crystal Snyder was directed to write two checks totaling $1,000 that will be sent to the Accomack Electric Cooperative, which is owned by 35,228 individuals in Northeast Accomack and Northampton who have accounts with it.
The checks will be returned to Crystal Snyder if she makes the payments because the amount is less than what the couple owes. Legislators are considering the establishment of a strategic environmental assessment system to evaluate the consequences of governmental policies and planning on the environment and to ensure sustainable development in the country.
Such a system will be legalized by a decree, which will directly enter the Bulgarian legislation.
Despite the growing interest towards sustainable development and attention towards measures of the environmental policy, a study conducted by experts from the Institute for Strategic Analysis in 2004 shows that environmental consequences are not consistently analyzed in DPDs in Bulgaria. The experts proposed a legalization of the environmental assessment in the country and management of such activities related to preparation of environmental impact assessment of the Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA).
Experts consider SEA system as an effective methodology and with great potential to solve problems with the protection of the environment as one of the essential components of the sustainable development policy. Many European countries, such as England and Sweden, France and Italy are within the process of introducing the system as a generalized assessment to enhance environmental quality and support sustainable development.

Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and include more links, hashtags and other content. According to Twitter, over 40 percent of tweets contain a retweeted tweet.
TechCrunch writes that the social site “understands the need to stay out of the content conversation unless absolutely necessary,” but such features mean that its never-ending flow of content may soon become so packed it starts to cripple individual users and brands.
“Once upon a time, you could count on one tweet per day to come from @Twitter to alert you to something new, a change in behavior or orientation,” TechCrunch says. “Now, maybe in a snapshot, you’ll see red in your timeline to highlight portions of the company it wants you to know about, but the majority of the time, it’s all that random mess, and it’s gotten a lot harder to separate the signal from the up-cy

Trade turnover between Russia and its second largest trade partner, Germany, increased 8.4 percent and reached nearly €62 billion ($70 billion) in 2018 compared to previous year, according to the German trade lobby. This was Germany’s biggest export market last year, after the US and China. It’s worth noting that Germany’s total trade turnover hit an all-time high in 2018.
Germany’s direct exports to Russia amounted to around €26.85 billion ($28.97 billion), remaining stable during the past five years. The biggest areas of imports from Russia to Germany meanwhile were minerals and fertilizers as well as products of non-ferrous metals.
Russia’s relations with Germany, its biggest foreign investor, have deteriorated since 2014 after Western powers imposed sanctions on Moscow over the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. In protest of the brutal tactics of Syria’s government, members of the hacktivist collective Anonymous have defaced the website of the Middle Eastern country’s Ministry of Defense, causing the site to completely shut down. The site remains inaccessible Tuesday, several days after its hackers claimed responsibility for its defacement. The hack comes amidst much concern in the Anonymous community regarding the fate of an American citizen death-row inmate and of two Turkish anti-censorship activists who recently faced similar ramifications of the Assad regime. Both Libya and China also face condemnation from the international hacktivist community, who remain active against government repression and censorship. Notable DDoS attacks have shut down Chinese government properties and have struck the Vatican. Syria isn’t the only notable government site to be hit this week, however. Remnants of bloody rule echo throughout Indonesian archipelago.
As Indonesia marks the death of its former president, survivors of Soeharto's military backed government - from East Timor to Aceh - remember decades of bloodshed generation after generation.
In the southern part of the Indonesian archipelago that famously spans about 17,000 islands, a pair of farmers recall an era far removed from a country once known as a peacekeeper in the region.
Much closer to New Zealand than Juntunen,Footnote 2 the area of Kupang, East Timor, was in a bloody conflict between the Indonesian military and pro-independence fighters roughly between 1961 and 1975. About 200,000 people died during that period, some estimates say.
Now Indonesia comes together to remember another dark era under former dictator Soeharto, who died while in bed rest at his Bogor palace in Jakarta on Monday, January 27.

The Seattle-based organization continues to march toward its mission of helping women entrepreneurs land funding and it’s getting support from key partners to do so. This past January, General Assembly, the bigger and bigger global learning company, announced it was backing FFA as if it were a prominent VC. In addition to previous partners such as Facebook and Microsoft, General Assembly receives access to gender-balanced networks and high-level curriculum development insights on company-building topics.
Since the beginning of its journey, FFA has faced three main obstacles to growing. Chief among them – funding. Despite statistics showing that women-led startups receive less than three percent of all venture capital in the US, FFA has managed to raise approximately $325,000 from almost 30 individual donors. A simple injection has helped a music lover get back to playing the piano again.
David Edmunds had been forced to give up playing and was also starting to have problems with driving after developing a problem that left his hand bent out of shape.
But after visiting Dreszler Hand and Upper Limb Rehabilitation in Sudbury a simple injection has got his finger curved back to a healthy angle and finally allowed him to get on with playing his favourite songs again.
“Once Dr. Dragos Drezler, general surgeon performing minimally invasive surgery altered the angle of the little finger joint to 45° the pain finally left, the strength came back. It was one of the most amazing feelings of relief and joy to know that my whole life was turned around and I could play. Now, every day plays, for an hour in the morning and in the evening.
“Thank you friends from all over the world, for your support and love, this last summer has been very difficult for me. I have to be honest, for the first time in my life, I have been thinking that my only passion, playing the piano, will never be possible again.

Serious allegations have been made about the deaths of civilians at the hands of Turkish security forces in the overwhelmingly Kurdish town of Cizre in south-eastern Turkey earlier this year.
Local officials say the security forces killed between 393 and 406 civilians during a 25-day curfew, imposed on the town from December 2015 to January this year, citing repeated attacks by the Kurdistan Workers’ Party (PKK) in the region.

The Navy plans to install a laser weapon prototype on a ship this summer for at-sea testing in the Persian Gulf.
The technology, called the Laser Weapon System, will be the first of its kind to fire a high-powered laser beam from a moving platform that includes sensor, targeting and aiming capabilities, the Navy's prime contractor for weaponry, Raytheon, announced March 13 in a press release.
The laser can be operated by sailors in helmets, allowing one crew member in systems control to target and fire at another crew member in reconnaissance who performs the aiming, the release states. The Navy has been working on the laser since 2015.
Elevating the laser and rays on a platform 60 feet above the water line can generate the effects needed for an attack, including shields.

Professors vary amongst themselves as to which students should write a "contract paper" versus a senior essay. Exceptions are those with grades of A, B, and C. By accepting a position, students are then asked to write a 20-page (minimum) single spaced paper on an issue of scholarly importance relevant to their classroom education, on-going research activities or teaching. They may choose a curricular topic, a scholarly article or engage in research and write a scholarly essay on the results of that research. It should not be required reading, but a scholarly essay demonstrating your depth of knowledge and, ultimately, your potential as a teacher-scholar. BEIJING — Mao Zedong famously dismissed the atomic bomb as a “paper tiger,” able to kill and terrify, but not decisive in war. Even so, China built a nuclear arsenal meant to terrorize the United States and deter America from intervening in a Pacific conflict.
China hasn’t attacked. The island is a democracy and a close economic and security partner of the United States. Beijing’s one serious military move during the Taiwan crisis was to fly a dozen missiles that were not ballistic over the island during a 10-day war scare in 1995.
Forty years after China’s first detonations, the nuclear tiger has become more a theater prop than true force on the battlefield. Pacifist China may well favor the appearance of unassailable nuclear power. The weapons might also help compete with a military that has been more stout of late. Lou Kerner of Wedbush Securities, who covers the social Web space, is fond of referring to Facebook as the second Internet. He calls it this, of course, because so much of what one can do on the open Web can now be done within the confines of Facebook.
Kerner also coined the term Social Media to include not just social networking sites, but other Web 2.0 developments like blogging and gaming. He and I were having a friendly e-mail debate about his theory on Friday. Kerner referenced Forrester’s Jay Krause. Kerner feels that the major social networks need to have something that he calls "social intelligence." I thought we might be communicating at cross purposes so I thought I would clarify what I mean.
Kerner defines social intelligence as "an application that uses a social network to share search results." In essence, the social network should serve as a platform, more akin to an open Web platform, than closed to allow the creative community the space it needs to develop the next ideas that allow the social web to grow to the next level. In my opinion, that is also the job of Brand Marketers.

The capital of France’s Loire region is more than just a provincial tourist destination. An hour’s drive from Brittany, Nantes is a lively city that has grown from medieval roots into a buzzing place to visit.
The Gates of Loire Bridge connects the city’s Old Town to its Château district. Built of wood, the bridge is one of the oldest in France. On our visit, its lively and festive air captured Ashton’s imagination. She asked, “Dad, are they having a party here?”
My husband, David, had visited eight years before with our daughter Saya. They had walked across the bridge, taking pictures, making a day of it. Once in Hanoi, they had shared her pictures and I instantly appreciated this fleeting nod to Nantes’ pretty French charm. Simultaneously quaint and modern, Nantes is surely a place to visit.

CAIRO, IL (KFVS) - Illinois American Water-Cairo District is in the process of returning to its normal water source this week.
Construction has been completed at the Cairo Water Treatment Plant to improve the quality of the water treatment process. Once the mustard, pepper smell returns to the water, they will naturally replace their effluent and draw water into the plant.
They were forced to use a new water source due to a Deal Island canal leak that forced them to pump into one reverse osmosis method, then pump to another.
The Cairo Transmission Main Project from the Deal Island canal continues to run behind schedule due to "unique water quality issues" and needed engineering-support assistance from Dublin, Ohio-based company Koch Membrane Systems.
This project maximizes Cairo District's use of reverse osmosis membranes and condensers, replacing the need for conventional filters and ultimately saves money for customers.
They anticipate final start-up at the transmission main will take place by February 1 or 2 of 2019. You can see photos of progress on its website.

Antibiotics kill pathogenic bacteria. However, they can also kill beneficial bacteria and upset the human body, especially in the gut. Scientists have developed a way to help protect ‘good’ bacteria by suspending antibiotics until they can identify colonizing animals without risk of transmission. Funded by the European and Irish governments, the work is a huge step forward in managing the use of antibiotics in Irish agriculture and driving the industry toward targeted application.
“By concurrently collecting samples from host animals and from farm surfaces we can identify specific marker genes that will alert us to the mammalian source of the faecal colonization,” Professor Donal Biswas of UCD’s Veterinary Bacterial Diseases Research Unit said. “Keeping animals separated from surfaces is best practice so the marker genes will tell us where a Faecal E coli sample originated so we can control its source and limitation.”
Different microbes contaminate different surfaces. The bacterial marker gene content of soil is different from contaminants at animal feeding and water mixing surfaces. E coli

Former Blackpool loanee Sean Longstaff has signed a new four-year deal with Newcastle United.
The midfielder spent last season on loan with the Seasiders, scoring nine times in 45 appearances.
Longstaff, whose brother Matty, is part of the Magpies’ current squad, joined the club in 2015 fron the Blackburn Rovers academy.
The reversal of last season's loan spell now sees him committed to the Tyne-Tyne club until 2020.
Longstaff has left Blackpool and has joined FC Twente on an undisclosed loan deal until the end of the season, after making just two starts since the summer arrival of Jermaine Sinclair.
The 20-year-old is available for selection in Twente's Europa League second leg at St Johnstone on Thursday night, although Blackpool have confirmed they will claim a percentage of the television revenue from that match.

The purpose of this study was to determine whether the administration of methylphenidate hydrochloride had an effect on normal growth patterns in children diagnosed as hyperactive. Subjects were assigned to one of three methylphenidate hydrocholaride algorithms, the first of which guaranteed no greater than a 3.0 meter-second squared difference in growth velocity. Six subjects completed the study on an outpatient basis at Riley Hospital for Children and were followed in terms of weight (Body Mass Index; BMI), height (standard deviation score), and standard linear skinfold measurements, in comparison to normal growth patterns. There was no significant difference in BMI between subjects and a small difference in standard linear skinfold measurements. Administration of methylphenidate hydrochloride does not alter the normal growth rate in growing children.

London agent Wetherell has announced the opportunity to buy the Little White House, the retreat from the White House where President George Washington frequented, for the first time in almost 50 years.

It is believed that he spent the equivalent of £180,000 of his estate on the building.

The storm that started hours earlier in southern Lower Michigan will intensify this afternoon and into this evening, according to the NWS.

Photo sharing site 500px announced on Friday plans to roll out Creative Commons licensing on the service.
While photos on the site will default to an “all rights reserved” setting, 500px users will have a legal framework available to license their photos for use by others. In order to do so, however, the photos must be marked as CC " sharing" or “sharable” as owner Michael Zhuo explains. Those two designations are separate and distinct licensing nuggets, ranging from being the freest form of sharing, requiring users to properly attribute the image and include elements of the image, down to "all-to-be-used-for-anything-ever" licenses that really are cake. For certain more specific markets like advertising, restrictions like appropriate age appropriateness and customized text can be placed on the image.
Creative Commons lets photographers mark the nature of sharing their images. The most permissive is “CC0” — the right to take the image and use it for anything. Photographers can specify a Creative Commons worldwide license to royalty free stock photo sites if they desire

Poor countries have won historic recognition of the plight they face from the ravages of climate change, wringing a pledge from rich nations that they will receive funds to repair the "loss and damage" incurred.
This week, the G7 group of developed countries, meeting in Germany, has committed $20bn in aid, doubling what they promised last year, to help poorer nations pay the steep costs of an escalation of climate change.
The money is a small fraction of the $300bn - $625bn each year for half a century - that they have calculated to meet the needs of the most climate-vulnerable countries. The cash will support and pay indemnity claims for nations ravaged by climate-related disasters such as floods, wildfires and monster storms, as well as their ongoing capacity to protect citizens, reinforce infrastructure and recover.

to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.

There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much of an urban icon as the MTA’s subway signage or the Chrysler building. Too bad they’re killing the planet.
It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. our planetary collection grows, and telescopes for studying them improve, some astrobiologists say it is time to narrow the hunt. Christopher McKay at NASA’s Ames Research Center in California has come up with an expanded “checklist” for habitability, which also considers factors like a planet’s light levels, radiation exposure and atmospheric composition (PNAS, DOI: 10.1073/pnas.1304212111).
Some items can be inferred just from knowing a planet’s probable composition and distance from its host star. Others will require photographing the planets and examining their atmospheres. Spacecraft with those capabilities are now being developed.
“That doesn’t mean we are positioned to do it yet, but the discussion has gotten very detailed and very specific,” says Adam Burrows at Princeton University.

Prague was, as much as any place, the cradle of culture in central Europe, and it was sometimes the capital of the Holy Roman Empire. Its ancient center was architecturally and many other ways romantic and gorgeous. Because it was subject only to rather minor bombing, Prague’s charm and beauty were nearly unscathed by World War II.
But 45 years of socialist “compassion” under a Soviet Union puppet regime had turned everything soot gray and ugly before eastern and central Europe was liberated in 1989.
When I arrived, you could walk down the winding cobblestone streets of the Old Town near its famous castle amid five-story ancient residential buildings standing shoulder-to-shoulder against narrow sidewalks on both sides. Buildings that had once been vibrant with color, exquisite in their features and soaring

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.
Land, water and biodiversity continue to decline. Global CO2 emissions are on the rise

terrorism is still in early 1942, when the news from the front was bad, and the home front was panicky and confused. Sometimes, the best-designed experiments fail. The effect you're looking for might not even occur, meaning that a null result should always be a possible outcome you're prepared for. When that happens, the experiment is often dismissed as a failure, even though you never would have known the results without performing it.
Yet, every once in a while, the apparatus that you build might be sensitive to something else entirely. When you do science in a new way, at a new sensitivity, or under new, unique conditions, that's often where the most surprising, serendipitous discoveries are made. In 1987, a failed experiment for detecting proton decay detected neutrinos, for the first time, from beyond not only our Solar System, but from outside of the Milky Way. This is how neutrino astronomy was born.

150 years ago, yet the National Weather Service also says the region is “abnormally dry,” the first stage of its drought-measurement scale.
No, climate change hasn’t driven weather folks crazy. The solution to the puzzle is that there are droughts and then there are droughts.
“There is a time lapse in how different systems respond to current conditions,” is how Richard Kiah, chief of Hydrologic Network Operations for the regional office of the U.S. Geological Survey, puts it.
In laymen’s terms: When wet weather appears, as it did in July, after a long stretch of very dry weather like we had this spring, the grass starts growing pretty quickly but it takes longer to fill up the aquifers that our wells depend on. A drought above ground might end, might even give way to flooding, while drought lingers below ground

Middle Ages. For almost fifty years, he was head or ‘successor’ (diadochos, sc. of Plato) of the Platonic ‘Academy’ in Athens. Kazakhstan's new interim president was sworn in Wednesday following the shock resignation of the country's long-time ruler and in his first official act renamed the capital after his predecessor.
Kassym-Jomart Tokayev took office in a pomp-filled ceremony less than 24 hours after Nursultan Nazarbayev, the only leader an independent Kazakhstan had ever known, suddenly announced he was stepping down.
Tokayev immediately proposed changing the name of the Central Asian nation's capital from Astana to Nursultan, or "Sultan of Light" in Kazakh, and parliament approved the change within hours.
The senate also appointed Nazarbayev's eldest daughter Dariga Nazarbayeva as speaker, setting her up as a potential contender to succeed her father.

. This bill is written with good intentions, but the implementation is a problem. The bill written by state Sen. Because of how the author and co-authors have chosen to fund the bill, it places these 4-year-olds in our public school system. I would imagine any person in the field of early childhood development; teacher, psychologist and doctor would oppose this bill.
The bill states that through longitudinal studies it has been found that those children who attended quality preschool programs had higher graduation rates, college enrollment rates and earning rates. This is what preschool educators have provided for years. Four-year-olds still need help developing social skills and gaining confidence. They need space inside and out allowing them to explore their environment. This will not happen at an elementary school.

as an act of nature not nurture. Identical twins go bald at the same age, rate and pattern, irrespective of diet, lifestyle or stress levels.
There's no need to go bald any more.
Baldness is a complex polygenic trait: up to five genes are involved, and it is the interplay between these genes, not unlike the interaction between the cards in a poker hand, that determine the specifics of male pattern hair loss.
So, what are the treatment options?
Finasteride is a Therapeutic Goods Administration-approved drug that dermatologists and general practitioners have been prescribing to treat hair loss for about 15 years.
It works by stopping the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone in the prostate, by blocking an enzyme called 5-alpha reductase.

this heart problem has dropped to almost nothing.
The trouble is that I switched to aspirin instead. Now I am having big-time bruising with the slightest bump. That convinced me to stop the aspirin.
I am going to try Tylenol, but I hope my liver enzymes don’t act up. They have been elevated in the past. Is there anything else I can do except stop everything and endure joint pain?
You have reason to be cautious with pain relievers. A recent online article in the British journal BMJ (July 4, 2011) suggests that anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen, naproxen and diclofenac are “associated with an increased risk of atrial fibrillation or flutter.” Such heart-rhythm abnormalities can trigger blood clots that may lead to strokes.

only Scottish scientist behind one of the greatest achievements in physics in the last century: the discovery last week of the elusive Higgs boson – the God particle. Although Higgs proposed the theory of the particle nearly 50 years ago, behind the scenes, dozens of physicists from Scotland played a vital role in the experiments which led to the identification of the Higgs boson – a particle which holds the key to explaining how matter attains its mass, and how the universe works at its most fundamental level.
The discovery awaits full endorsement from the scientific community.
Around 50 academics, researchers, technicians and postgraduate students from both Glasgow and Edinburgh universities were part of the Atlas experiment team at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in Cern, Switzerland, which announced the breakthrough on Wednesday.

er, Philip Roth got his wish: Wikipedia has changed its entry on his novel The Human Stain to indicate the proper source for its protagonist Coleman Silk. The young Mark Coleridge was preparing to take the field in a cricket match in a park surrounding Rome’s picturesque Villa Doria Pamphili in the 1980s when a bemused local approached.
It was not an entirely surprising reaction. Cricket was virtually unknown in Italy at the time, having been outlawed by Benito Mussolini before World War II, as it was considered to be inextricably connected with England.
“There was always a bit of a crowd stopping to watch us playing,” Archbishop Coleridge said.
Nonetheless, there was one place in Rome where Mussolini could not entirely exert his power: the Vatican.
“Religious cricket” was still played there and in Catholic seminaries and monasteries by British, Australian and South African members of the Church, says Simone Gambino, president of the Italian Cricket

books? Imagine a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Researchers at Missouri University of Science and Technology under engineering professor Reza Zoughi have developed a patented device that can show the inner structures of objects in real time by using millimeter and microwave signals.
Potential applications include the detection of cancerous skin cells, termite damage to buildings, or concealed weapons at secure zones like airports.
The tech could also be used for finding "defects in thermal insulating materials that are found in spacecraft heat insulating foam and tiles, space habitat structures, aircraft radomes and composite-strengthened concrete bridge members," Zoughi was quoted as saying in a release.

NEW YORK – The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The new policy, aimed at easing a controversy that has embroiled the Boy Scouts for decades, would take effect immediately if approved by the organization’s 80-member National Executive Board. Its members were convening for a closed-to-the-media meeting conducted by teleconference.
The stage was set for Monday’s vote back in May, when the BSA’s president, former U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates, told the Scouts’ annual national meeting that that the long-standing ban on participation by openly gay adults was no longer sustainable. -- Haiti's capital seemed to spring back to life Wednesday, more than a week after a 7.0-magnitude earthquake flattened many parts of the city and killed tens of thousands.
Electrical power was still out most places, but traffic lights were functioning and chaotic traffic clogged many streets. Aid trucks, some guarded by blue-helmeted United Nations peacekeepers, were seen leaving the airport. Water trucks also were spotted in parts of Port-au-Prince.
"There's energy in the air," said Haitian-born J.B. Diederich, who lives in Miami but returned to Haiti for a few days after the earthquake.
More U.N. convoys were seen moving through the city than in previous days, and so could vehicles for large nongovernmental organizations.
